questions.text: A patient with sarcoidosis shows Koeppe's nodules on ophthalmologic examination. Where are these seen?
questions.solution:
Koeppe's nodules and Bussaca's nodules develop on the iris in granulomatous uveitis.

Koeppe's nodules are seen at the pupillary margin. Bussaca's nodules are seen on the peripheral part of the anterior surface of iris.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child post-tonsillectomy comes to you with complaints of snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing and a slight decrease in hearing. On examination, you notice a high-arched palate. His school performance has deteriorated as well. His mother is worried. What is the next line of management for this child?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy causing eustachian tube obstruction. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

Glue ear is thought to happen due to either malfunctioning (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the eustachian tube (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. Mild earaches with a history of upper respiratory tract infection are usually seen. 

On otoscopy, 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • If the tympanic membrane is transparent fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen

 

The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques. 
  • Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the detection of hemosiderin deposits?
questions.solution:
Perl's prussian blue stain is used to detect hemosiderin deposits.

Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived granular pigment that is golden-yellow to brown. It accumulates in the tissues when there is a local or systemic excess of iron.

Iron is normally stored within cells in association with the protein apoferritin, forming ferritin micelles. Large aggregates of these micelles are hemosiderin deposits seen both in light and electron microscopy. 

Image 1: Hemosiderin deposits in tissue

Image 2: Prussian blue staining of hemosiderin

*Note: Iron dispersed in the cytoplasm is seen in electron microscopy as ferritin micelles.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented to the clinic with a lump in her right breast is diagnosed to have breast carcinoma. All of the following are favorable prognostic markers except ______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario explains breast carcinoma and HER2 overexpression is associated with poor survival.

The main importance of HER2 status is as a predictor of response to agents that target this receptor. Luminal A subtype i.e well-differentiated, ER-positive, HER2-negative, and low proliferation, has the most favorable prognosis.

The proliferative rate can be measured by mitotic counts or by immunohistochemical detection of Ki67 proteins. Carcinomas with high prolifera­tion rates have a poorer prognosis.

  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Metaplastic carcinoma
  • Micropapillary carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding oxytocin?

choices.text: It can be given by oral route
It is secreted by anterior pituitary
In higher doses, it exerts diuretic like action

questions.solution:
Oxytocin is responsible for galactokinesis (milk ejection reflex).

Other options:

  • It can not be given by oral route because it has emotional side effects.
  • It is secreted by the posterior pituitary.
  • It does not have diuretic-like action at higher doses.

WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL) recommends oxytocin administration immediately (within 1 minute) after the delivery of the fetus.  Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. It should be given after the delivery of the fetus and before the delivery of the placenta. 

Milk ejection by oxytocin follows a stimulation mechanism similar to uterine contraction in delivery (cervical dilatation). 

The physiological actions of oxytocin are: 

  • Contraction of the pregnant uterus: Cervical dilatation transmits signals to the hypothalamus and stimulates the secretion of oxytocin, which acts on the smooth muscles of the uterus and contracts it. 
  • Milk ejection from breasts: Suckling reflex transmits signals to the hypothalamus which causes the release of oxytocin which acts on the myoepithelial cells of the breast. This results in ejection of milk. 

The action of oxytocin is an example of positive feedback mechanism. 

AMTSL  guidelines recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

questions.text: The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is _____
questions.solution:
The hormone involved in the regulation of blood pressure is angiotensin II.

Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor that increases the total peripheral resistance and decreases Na+ and H2O excretion by kidney, thereby causing an increase in arterial BP.

questions.text: Which of the following describes LD50?

choices.text: 50% animal mortality in an experiment, after exposure to the drug
50% reduction of infection in the given population of experimental animals
Dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.
Range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low

questions.solution:
LD50 (median lethal dose) is the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die, after exposure to the drug. 

Larger the LD50, the safer the drug. 

In humans, TD50 is considered. TD50 refers to the dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.

Other options: 

Option B: ED50 is the dose of the drug at which there is 50% reduction of infection in the given population of experimental animals, or the dose at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect. 

Option C: TD50 is the dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population.

Option D: Therapeutic window refers to the range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is unemployed because he is unable to walk after an accident. His unemployment is classified as a _______
questions.solution:
The patient here being unemployed can be classified as handicap, according to the concept given below.

Disease → Impairment → Disability → Handicap

  • Impairment is any loss or abnormality in normal structure or function.
  • Disability is the inability to carry out normal actions due to impairment.
  • Handicap is experiencing disadvantages due to disability and inability to discharge obligations normally.

In the given example:

  • Accident: Disease (or disorder)
  • Loss of foot: Impairment (extrinsic or intrinsic)
  • Cannot walk: Disability (objectified)
  • Unemployed: Handicap (socialized)

questions.text: A patient came to the casualty with acute bronchial asthma after treatment for glaucoma. Which of the following is most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used in glaucoma. Non-selective beta-blockers can cause precipitation of bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals (beta-2 block on bronchi).

Ocular beta-blockers reduce Intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation by blockade of β2 receptors. The most commonly prescribed non‐selective beta‐blocker eye drops is timolol and eye drops significantly affect lung function and increase asthma morbidity.

Betaxolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma. (option B)

Latanoprost and bimatoprost are prostaglandin (PGF2 alpha) analogs and does not precipitate bronchial asthma. (option C and D)

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The posterior tibial artery is palpated between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal tendon, as shown in the image.

The posterior tibial artery can be felt by keeping the foot relaxed between plantar and dorsiflexion and palpating against the distal tibia behind and below the medial malleolus, approximately one-third of a line connecting the posterior border of the medial malleolus to the calcaneal tendon(Achilles tendon)

Other options:

Option A: The anterior tibial artery is palpated on the dorsum of the foot, lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon. This pulse point is important for assessing peripheral circulation in the lower limb.

Option C: Dorsalis pedis artery is palpated against the underlying tarsals, lateral to the tendon of extensor hallucis longus from the midpoint between the malleoli to the proximal end of the first intermetatarsal space. 

Option D: The popliteal artery is the most difficult of the peripheral pulses to feel because the artery lies deep in the popliteal fossa. It is examined with the subject lying supine or prone, with the knee flexed to relax the tense popliteal fascia that roofs the popliteal fossa. It is felt over the midline of the fossa by deep pressure against the popliteal surface of the femur. 

Arteries of the lower limb are mentioned in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following factors should be kept in mind while choosing the power of an intraocular lens (IOL) in a child  <1 year of age?

choices.text: Growth of the lens capsule with age

questions.solution:
A myopic shift is a common occurrence post IOL implantation is children <1 year of age. The rate of shift occurs most rapidly during the first one and one-half years of life. In general, earlier the surgery and IOL implantation, larger is the myopic shift.

Other options:

  • Hyperopic shifts occur when either the effective axial eye length is decreased (i.e. retrobulbar tumors, choroidal tumors, central serous chorioretinopathy) or when the refractive power of the eye is reduced (i.e. corneal flattening, decreased refractive power of the lens (cataractous changes, posterior displacement

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the below image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis here is Mycetoma which is caused by Eumycetoma.

Mycetoma:-

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as Maduramycosis or Madura foot. Mycetoma occurs worldwide.
  • Etiology:  It can be divided into three types, eumycetomas, actinomycetomas and botryomycosis.

Pathogenesis:-

  • Triad of symptoms: Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources, usually on thorns or splinters and results in tumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging fungal colonies called grains or granules (triad of symptoms). 
  • Subcutaneous tissues of the feet, lower extremities, hands, and exposed areas are most often involved.
  • Grains: Within host tissues the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • A. Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.
  • B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

Treatment:-

The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: In a fasting state, glucagon promotes the production of glucose by which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
The source of blood glucose in a fasting state is Gluconeogenesis and Glycogenolysis. It is promoted by glucagon.

The first stage of fasting: The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting i.e; 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 11 hours will be liver glycogenolysis.

Second stage of fasting: Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days.

Substrates for gluconeogenesis are:

  • Glucogenic amino acids ( mainly alanine) from the muscle and
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue 

During fasting, the glucogenic amino acids are transported to the liver, transaminated into pyruvate, and converted to glucose.

Third stage of fasting:

  • Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by increased glucagon: insulin ratio.
  • Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. Triacylglycerols will be hydrolyzed to fatty acids and glycerol. 
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place which provides acetyl CoA. 
  • In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs.

Final stage of fasting: After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin. Hence glucagon: insulin ratio is increased.

Effects of increased glucagon: insulin ratio on enzymes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis:

  1. It activates glycogen phosphorylase, the key enzyme of glycogenolysis, and deactivates glycogen synthase. This causes a rapid mobilization of liver glycogen stores to be utilized as fuel.
  2. It favors the synthesis of glucose-6-phosphatase which converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. The resulting glucose is used by red blood cells (lack mitochondria) and the brain as they are largely dependent on glucose in the fasting state.
  3. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase and fructose-1, 6-bisphosphatase are induced, leading to increased gluconeogenesis.
Metabolic process         Fasting state      Fed state
Glucagon: insulin   Increased              Decreased
Gluconeogenesis    Increased                Decreased            
Glycogenolysis  Increased                Decreased
Ketogenesis  Increased                Decreased
Glycogen storage  Decreased  Increased

questions.text: Till when can you perform MTP on the grounds of contraceptive failure?
questions.solution:
As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Bill 2020, the induction of MTP on grounds of contraceptive failure can be done only until until 20 weeks. 

The MTP Act of 2021 specifies special circumstances for termination of pregnancy beyond 20 weeks till 24 weeks of gestation. These include:

  • Survivor of sexual assault, rape or incest.
  • Minors
  • Mentally ill women including mental retardation
  • Change of marital status during the ongoing pregnancy (widowhood and divorce)
  • Women with physical disabilities (Major disability criteria - Rights of persons with disabilities act - 2016)
  • Women with pregnancy in humanitarian settings or disaster or emergency situations as declared by the government.
  • Fetal malformations that have a substantial risk of being incompatible with life or if the child is born, may suffer from serious physical or mental
  • abnormalities to be seriously handicapped. (Option A)

Termination of pregnancy can be done only up to 20 weeks based on grounds of contraception failure.

  • Until 20 weeks of gestation - Opinion of one doctor  
  • 20-24 weeks of gestation - Opinion of two doctors
  • The name and particulars of the woman whose pregnancy has been terminated cannot be disclosed. It can only be revealed to a person in force authorised by law. The ground for failure of contraception is extended to women and their partners.
     

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in MCP joints and his serum uric acid levels were found to be elevated. His physician prescribed a drug which is considered as the first line agent in the management of this condition. What is the mechanism of this drug?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is recommended as the first-line urate-lowering agent in all patients with gout. It is a purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase enzyme.

It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acid levels. Allopurinol is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase. The metabolite of allopurinol called oxypurinol is a non-competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.  

Febuxostat is a uric acid synthesis inhibitor that acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase and it is indicated in gout management.

Both Febuxostat and Allopurinol are Xanthine Oxidase inhibitors, of which Allopurinol is a hypoxanthine analog.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of intense itching, photophobia, and ropy discharge from his eyes. Moreover, on examination the following finding is present. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a cobblestone appearance, and also the presence of ropy discharge points towards the diagnosis of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or spring catarrh.

VKC is bilateral allergic conjunctivitis that is common in children above the age of 5 years and in warm dry climates such as the Mediterranean, sub-Saharan Africa, and the Middle East.

It is IgE and cell-mediated inflammation of the conjunctiva. It results in the following findings:

Palpebral disease

  • Cobblestone papillae: Macropapillae (<1 mm) have a flat-topped polygonal appearance reminiscent of cobblestones
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal disease

  • Horner-Trantas dots which are limbal conjunctival papillae

Keratopathy

  • Superior punctate epithelial erosions
  • Shield ulcers, which may develop when the exposed Bowman membrane becomes coated with mucus and calcium phosphate, leading to inadequate wetting and delayed re-epithelialization.
  • Pseudogerentexon resembling arcus senilus. It has a cupid's bow outline

Treatment of VKC includes allergen avoidance, antihistaminics, steroids, and immunomodulators both topical and systemic depending on the severity of the disease.

Other options:

  • Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage. The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms).
  • Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Xerophthalmia is a term used to cover all ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Image: Horner Trantas spots

questions.text: Angular conjunctivitis is caused by _______.
questions.solution:
Moraxella species,which are gram negative diplobacillus are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the inner and outer canthi with excoriation of skin and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.

Causes: 

  • Moraxella axenfeld
  • Moraxella lacunata
  • Moraxella catarrhalis
  • Staphylococcus aureus (rare) 

Source of infection: Nasal tract of healthy people and the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis

Mode of spread: From the nasal cavity to the eye by contaminated hands and handkerchief

Treatment

  • Oxytetracycline for 10 to 14 days 
  • Zinc oxide inhibits proteolytic ferment.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked below.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is Pons. 

Pons houses the motor nucleus of the facial nerve, and also the vestibulocochlear nuclei and abducens nuclei.

The pneumotaxic center is located in the upper pons.

Neural regulation of respiration:

It involves set of neurons located in pons and medulla:

  • Pons: Pneumotaxic centre and apneustic centre (mnemonic PAP: Pons Pneumotaxic center Apneustic center)
  • Medulla: Pre-Botzinger complex
    • Dorsal respiratory group
    • Ventral respiratory group

5th nerve nuclei: the motor nucleus is situated medially and sensory nucleus laterally in the pons. The spinal trigeminal nucleus is a caudal continuation of the main sensory nucleus, extending from the mid pons through the medulla to the cervical spinal cord.

The 6th nerve nucleus is found near the midline in the floor of the fourth ventricle just lateral to the medial longitudinal fasciculus in the pons.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass filled the nasal cavity and eroded the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discolouration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment:

  • Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.
  • Surgical debridement
  • Control of underlying predisposing causes.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: During a measles epidemic in the community, a 6-month-old child was vaccinated against the same. When should the second dose be administered to this child?

choices.text: The child should be given a second dose as soon as she reaches 9 months of age
The child should be given a second dose after 2 weeks of last dose
The child should be given a second dose after 6 weeks of last dose
The child should be given the second dose of measles at 12 months of age

questions.solution:
An infant immunized between 6-9 months should receive a second dose as soon as the child reaches 9 months of age.

While the scheduled age of receiving the 1st dose of measles vaccine is at 9 months, it can be lowered to 6 months during a measles epidemic in the community. For infants immunized between 6 months to 9 months of age, a second dose should be administered as soon as the child reaches the age of 9 months, provided that 4 weeks have elapsed since the last dose.

questions.text: A farmer is brought to the hospital 8 hours later, following a snake bite. He complained of headache, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, dizziness, vertigo, and multiple episodes of vomiting since the bite. He has signs of respiratory depression and a pulse <50. The local wound showed mild swelling and blistering. There are no apparent bleeding manifestations. He was administered 10 vials of antivenom. Which of the following is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a neurotoxic snake bite. Since this patient has already passed 8 hours without any bleeding manifestations, the bite of a hemotoxic snake is unlikely and the better management would be to address his neurotoxic symptoms with the administration of neostigmine with atropine.

The neurotoxic symptoms are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs, such as neostigmine. Atropine is administered to counter the muscarinic side effects of neostigmine. 

Neurotoxic symptoms include: 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Perioral paraesthesia (tingling sensation around the mouth)
  • Vomiting
  • Dizziness
  • Vertigo
  • Hyperacusis
  • Gooseflesh
  • Hypersalivation

Respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, at this stage or later. If it progresses to paralysis, it initially presents with ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia, which may appear between a few minutes after the bite or after some hours.

ASV(Anti Snake Venom) is the mainstay of snakebite treatment. Neurotoxicity effects may wear off spontaneously in about a week and are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase. Atropine can be used in the management of venom that acts postsynaptically. Ventilatory support is provided in cases complicated with severe respiratory depression, in the event of failure of other measures of management. 

ASV used in India is effective against:

  • Cobra
  • Common krait
  • Russel viper
  • Saw scaled viper

Measures that can be done in the case of snakebite:

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Clean the wound with soap and water, or iodine and cover it with a sterile dressing 
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap) on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. 
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb

questions.text: A child is infected with a negative sense RNA virus which also contains neuraminidase receptors. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Influenza virus is a segmented, negative-sense/negative-strand RNA virus with neuraminidase receptors/peplomers projecting from the envelope. It belongs to the family of orthomyxoviruses. The hemagglutinin and neuraminidase receptors are present as two different spikes on the envelope. 

Parainfluenza virus, Newcastle disease virus, and Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) are negative-sense single-stranded RNA viruses with a linear genome. No neuraminidase is seen.

questions.text: The lab technician notices a urine sample from a 4-year-old male that was normal on collection but turns into the colour shown in the image after a few hours. It further darkened over the next few hours. Deficiency of which of the following can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Urine turning dark in colour on long-standing is a characteristic feature of alkaptonuria caused by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.

The dark colour of the urine on standing is due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid.

Features of alkaptonuria:

  • It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.
  • Large amounts of homogentisic acid are formed, which are excreted in urine or deposited in tissues.
  • Clinical manifestations of alkaptonuria consist of ochronosis and arthritis in adulthood. Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, and knee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications.

Ochronosis : Bluish black discoloration of sclera and ear cartilage due to deposition of homogentisic acid, beginning in late adolescence.

Other options:

A. Beta-carotene: Beta-carotene is a pigment that can give a yellow or orange color to certain foods and, to some extent, can affect the color of urine. However, beta-carotene deficiency is not associated with the darkening of urine on long-standing. It is not a characteristic feature of beta-carotene deficiency.

B. Tyrosine aminotransferase: Tyrosine aminotransferase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of the amino acid tyrosine. However, deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase is not known to cause darkening of urine on long-standing. Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency is a very rare condition and is associated with symptoms related to impaired tyrosine metabolism, such as neurological and developmental issues.

C. L-ascorbic acid: L-ascorbic acid, also known as vitamin C, is an antioxidant and plays a role in various metabolic processes. While high doses of vitamin C supplements can sometimes cause changes in urine color, such as a more yellow or orange hue, deficiency of L-ascorbic acid is not associated with darkening of urine on long-standing. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) is characterized by symptoms such as fatigue, joint pain, and skin changes.

questions.text: A handwashing awareness session was conducted in a community. The correct sequence of events here is:
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of events in this health awareness session is: awareness > interest > evaluation > adoption.

 1. Awareness Stage: The individual becomes aware of the innovation. He is exposed to innovation but has only limited information about it. At this stage, he doesn’t give much attention to the new product. 

2. Interest and Information Stage: The individual becomes interested in innovation and tries to collect more information. He tries to know about qualities, features, functions, risk, producers, brand, colour, shape, price, incentives, availability, services, and other relevant aspects.

3. Evaluation Stage: The consumer considers accumulated information and use it to evaluate the innovation and judge the worth of innovation. He compares different aspects of innovation like qualities, features, performance, price, after-sales services, etc., with the existing products to arrive at the decision whether the innovation should be tried out.

4. Adoption Stage: If trial produces satisfactory results, finally the consumer decides to adopt/buy the innovation. He purchases the product.

The four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach
Regulatory approach Service approach  Health Education approach Primary health care approach
Government intervention to alter human behaviour laws Facilities are provided by the government for use Awareness-> interest->Evaluation The health of the people, for the people, by the people where principles of community participation and intersectoral coordination are stressed
Ex: Child marriage Act, No smoking in public places; Helmet law Ex: The government provided latrines free of cost yet people did not use them because its need was not felt Ex: Adoption of ORS for diarrhoea

questions.text: Which of the following is the most significant side-effect of tamoxifen?
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and it is the drug of choice for preventing recurrence of breast carcinoma in pre-menopausal women. The most significant side-effect of tamoxifen is endometrial hyperplasia. 

It has an agonistic action on the endometrium, leading to an increased risk of endometrial cancers. Hence, it is not used in post-menopausal women.

The estrogen agonistic action of tamoxifen and its consequences are:

  • Uterine endometrium: Endometrial hypertrophy, vaginal bleeding and endometrial cancer
  • Coagulation system: Thromboembolism leading to pulmonary embolism (Tamoxifen decreases the level of antithrombin III and protein c in the blood).
  • Bone metabolism: Decrease in bone mineral density (in premenopausal women), leading to an increased risk of fractures due to osteoporosis. Increase in bone mineral density (in postmenopausal women).
  • Liver: Alterations of blood lipid profile.
  • Tamoxifen use is associated with cataracts 
  • Fertility: Tamoxifen may interfere with implantation and may cause infertility, but is not a significant side effect.

If a patient on tamoxifen develops abnormal uterine bleeding, the drug needs to be stopped.

The use of tamoxifen in carcinoma of breast patients decreases the incidence of carcinoma in opposite breasts (Option A).

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is macrocytic anaemia seen?
questions.solution:
Liver disease features non-megaloblastic macrocytic normochromic anaemia.

MCV >100 fl indicates macrocytic anaemia. The causes for the same, divided by morphology, are:

  • Megaloblastic:

    Vitamin B12 deficiency

    Folate deficiency

    Thiamine deficiency

    Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, Hydroxyurea

    Orotic aciduria

  • Non-megaloblastic:

    Alcohol use

    Liver disease

    Hypothyroidism

    Hemolysis*

 

*Note: Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with fungal infection of sinuses and peri-orbital region with significant visual impairment as shown below. The most appropriate drug for the treatment of this patient is ________.
questions.solution:
The description of the patient typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection in diabetes mellitus, leukaemia and lymphoma. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is responsible for the following natural process?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin helps in the ejection of milk by myoepithelial contraction which can be felt as cramps.

     Functions of oxytocin are:

  • Milk ejection (Myoepithelial contraction)
  • ADH like action in high doses (reduces urine output)
  • Uterine contraction

Hormones acting on breast

Function Definition Hormone
Mammogenesis Breast growth and development

Estrogen (Ductal growth)

Progesterone (Alveolar growth)
Lactogenesis Inititation of milk secretion Prolactin
Galactokinesis Ejection of milk Oxytocin
Galactopoiesis Maintanence of lactation Prolactin

questions.text: Urea cycle and Krebs cycle are linked at the enzyme____.
questions.solution:
Urea cycle and Krebs cycle are linked at the enzyme fumarate.

In the Urea cycle, cleavage of argininosuccinate to arginine releases the aspartate skeleton as fumarate.

Fumarate in Krebs cycle, by addition of water, converts to  L-malate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhoea not responding to antibiotics. On examination, granulation tissue is seen in EAC, facial nerve palsy was present. The likely diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
Elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea, and granulation tissue in EAC and facial nerve palsy indicates malignant otitis externa.

It is termed malignant, though being an infection due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa:

  • Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of EAC.
  • Facial paralysis is common.
  • Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease. Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient

The treatment of malignant otitis external would include control of diabetes, ear toileting to remove the discharge, debris or granulation tissue, antibiotic therapy against Pseudomonas with fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins, beta-lactam antibiotics with/without aminoglycosides.

If the patient is not responsive, culture and sensitivity of ear discharge should be done.

questions.text: If a sample is cultured in LJ media, what would be the staining characteristic of the organism?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium tuberculosis exhibits an acid-fast property when stained with a differential stain such as the Ziehl-Neelsen method. Lowenstein-Jenson medium is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture. The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis resists decolorisation by 20% sulphuric acid and is therefore called acid-fast. 

Colony characteristics on LJ Medium:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies with a wrinkled surface, tenacious, difficult to emulsify, creamy white and buff-colored (rough, tough, buff). 

Mycobacterium bovis forms moist, smooth, flat, white colonies on LJ media that break up easily when touched. 

Components of LJ medium:

  • Egg: Provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism.
  • Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants.
  • Mineral salt solution: Buffer.
  • Glycerol: Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis.
  • L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction(HFrEF)?
questions.solution:
Digoxin does not reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF.

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF are :

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)
  • Beta blockers
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists

questions.text: The CT scan of a 1-week old infant revealed the ​absence of greater cornu of the hyoid and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition?
questions.solution: Greater horn (greater cornu) and lower part of the body of the hyoid bone are formed from the 3rd pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: A cross-sectional view of a skeletal muscle fiber through the H zone would reveal the presence of  _______
questions.solution:
H zone is the central region of the A band which is lighter than the outer edges of the A band. This is because the H zone is occupied by thick laments only (no cross bridges)

In the figure, note the section through various levels and the myofilaments observed.

  • Section through I band → only actin (thin filament)
  • Section through A band (excluding H zone) →actin and myosin
  • Section through H zone → only myosin (thick filament)
  • Section through M line → thick filament linked with accessory proteins
  • Section at AI junction → both actin and myosin

questions.text: In the WHO grading of astrocytomas, which grade does glioblastoma fall under?
questions.solution:
Glioblastoma multiforme falls under WHO Grade IV of astrocytomas. It has the worst long-term prognosis with a median survival of roughly 1 year.

Astrocytomas (Graded I to IV) are the most common primary CNS neoplasm. The term often is used to refer to astrocytomas specifically, excluding other glial tumours.

  • Grade I - Pilocytic astrocytoma
  • Grade II - Diffuse astrocytoma
  • Grade III - Anaplastic astrocytoma
  • Grade IV - Glioblastoma multiforme

questions.text: A child visited the hospital with her mother with complaints of severe fatigue, lethargy, pallor and irritation. She is a known case of iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) and is on oral iron supplements. On reviewing the child, the physician in charge plans to start IV iron supplementation. What is the next best test to be done in assessing this child?
questions.solution:
Assessing serum ferritin is the next best step in this diagnosed case of iron deficiency anaemia (IDA). 

The reference standard to diagnose and monitor IDA is serum ferritin level. A decrease in the same is the earliest sign of IDA.

Since it is expensive and not widely available, an inexpensive & simpler way of evaluation is the Mentzer index.

The progression to iron deficiency develops in 3 stages:

  • Stage of negative iron balance - Decrease in iron stores with normal serum iron and RBC morphology
  • Stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis - Decrease in serum iron levels with normal RBC morphology
  • Stage of iron deficiency anaemia - Microcytic hypochromic RBCs.

questions.text: Of the following, which organism cannot be grown on an artificial culture media?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium leprae cannot be grown in a pure culture medium. It does not obey Koch's postulates and cannot be grown in vitro.

Mycobacterium leprae is an obligate intracellular bacillus confined to humans, armadillos, and in some locales, sphagnum moss. It is the only bacterium which invades peripheral nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following would help in explaining the mechanism of action of  ANP (atrial natriuretic peptide)?
questions.solution:
Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) increases intracellular cGMP by activating the enzyme guanylyl cyclase.

ANP is secreted by the heart from atrial storage granules in response to an increase in intravascular volume. It decreases aldosterone secretion and decreases blood pressure. 

Option A: cAMP is increased by activation of adenyl cyclase. Norepinephrine is a hormone that acts on intracellular adenylyl cyclase. 

Option C: Gi of G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR) act via the IP3-DAG (phospholipase C) pathway. 

Option D: Tyrosine kinase receptors act via the JAK/STAT pathway.

Mineralocorticoids

questions.text: 6 year old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Management includes
questions.solution: Swelling in the nose indicates possibility of septal haematoma which mainly presents with bilateral nasal obstruction and needs immediate surgical drainage.

questions.text: A young boxer receives a blow near the eye during a boxing match. He presents to the ER with hematoma around eye, CT scan is shown below. Identify the radiological sign shown below?
questions.solution:
The given CT image dipicts 'tear-drop' sign and suggests a blowout fracture.

Tear-drop/ hanging drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. The most useful projection for detecting an orbital floor fracture is Water’s view.

An orbital blow-out fracture is an isolated fracture of the orbital floor when a large blunt object strikes the globe is called blow out fracture. The orbital contents herniate through the antrum. Clinical signs are periocular swelling (early stage), enophthalmos, ecchymosis and subconjunctival haemorrhage (later stages).

Initial treatment consists of observation, oral antibiotics, ice packs, and nasal decongestants. Indications for surgery in a blowout fracture include diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma, a fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum, incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in globe retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze and enophthalmos. If any of these conditions are present, surgical correction is required within 2 weeks.

The below-given X-ray image in the Water's view shows a 'tear-drop' sign

The optimal time for surgery following a blow-out fracture is 10–14 days.

Indications for surgery in a "blow-out" fracture are as follows:

  • Diplopia not resolving significantly in the early days after trauma
  • A fracture with a large herniation of tissues into the antrum
  • Incarceration of tissues in the fracture, resulting in  globe  retraction and increased applanation tension on attempted upward gaze
  • Enophthalmos greater than 2 mm
     

Other options:

Option A: Panda sign: A radiological finding in sarcoidosis showing bilateral symmetrical uptake in the lacrimal and parotid glands on gallium scan, creating an appearance resembling a panda's face.

Option B: Dalrymple’s sign is the commonest and earliest sign of Grave's ophthalmopathy. It is due to overactivity of levator aponeurosis and Müller's muscle. Here the upper lid margin is at level with or above the superior limbus, causing the upper sclera to become visible (scleral show).

Option C: Munson's sign is seen in keratoconus. There is a localized bulging of the lower eyelid that can be seen in a downward-looking eye.

questions.text: Which of the following features aids in the differentiation of a true bruise from an artificial bruise?

choices.text: Progression of the color of bruise over time

questions.solution:
One of the features of differentiation of a true bruise from an artificial bruise is the progression of the color of the bruise over time. 

Other options: 

Options A, C, and D: Positive chemical tests, regular and well-defined margins, and the presence of vesicles are features of an artificial bruise. 

Artificial bruises are caused by the application of certain irritant substances such as the juice of marking nut, calotropis, or plumbago rosea to simulate true bruises.

The following features can be used to distinguish between the two categories.

Trait Artificial bruise True bruise
Site Accessible parts Anywhere
Color Dark brown Typical color progression over time
Shape Irregular Rounded
Margins Well defined and regular Ill-defined and irregular
Vesicles Present Absent
Redness/ Inflammation Present in the surrounding skin Present over bruise
Itching Present Absent
Chemical tests Positive Negative

questions.text: A tall obese person, who is a known hypertensive was recently diagnosed with metabolic syndrome on routine workup. Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Increase in uric acid and insulin
Increase in triglycerides and total cholesterol

questions.solution:
Increase in triglycerides and total cholesterol is seen in patients with metabolic syndrome.

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education program and adult treatment panel III). It includes-

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented to the clinic with complaints of  episodic vertigo,  sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What is the possible clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The possible clinical diagnosis for a 35-year-old male presenting with episodic vertigo, ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus is Meniere's disease. It is also called endolymphatic hydrops.

The primary pathology in Ménière’s disease is the distension of the endolymphatic system due to an increased endolymph volume. This can result either from increased production of endolymph or its faulty absorption or both. Normally, endolymph secreted by stria vascularis, fills the membranous labyrinth, and is absorbed through the endolymphatic sac.

Meniere's disease is a chronic condition of the inner ear that affects balance and hearing. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, which are brief and intense episodes of spinning dizziness. Patients may also experience a sense of pressure or fullness in the affected ear, along with fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus (ringing or buzzing in the ear). The tinnitus associated with Meniere's disease is typically low-tone roaring in nature.

Other options:

  • Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is another common cause of vertigo, but it is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by specific head movements, such as rolling over in bed or looking up. BPPV does not typically cause ear pressure, hearing loss, or low-tone roaring tinnitus.
  • Labyrinthitis is an inflammation of the inner ear, usually caused by a viral or bacterial infection. It can cause vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus, but it is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as ear pain, fever, and a general feeling of illness.
  • Syncope refers to a temporary loss of consciousness and muscle tone, often caused by a decrease in blood flow to the brain. It is not associated with the symptoms described in the scenario, such as vertigo, ear pressure, hearing loss, or tinnitus.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the Michaelis-Menten graph?

choices.text: Km is directly proportional to substrate concentration
Km is directly proportional to enzyme concentration
Km is indirectly proportional to substrate concentration
Km has no relation to substrate concentration

questions.solution:
The Michaelis-Menten equation/graph represents the enzymatic rate (Km) at different substrate concentrations i.e Km is directly proportional to substrate concentration

For a typical enzyme, as the substrate concentration increases, initial velocity (Vi) increases until it reaches a maximum value Vmax. With further increase in the substrate concentration, the enzyme is said to be “saturated” with the substrate and the velocity remains the same. Hence, the shape of the curve that relates to the velocity of the reaction to substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

The Michaelis-Menten equation illustrates mathematically the relationship between Vi and [S] i.e,

Vi = Vmax ×[S]/Km+[S]

The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which Vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2).

The plot of initial reaction velocity against substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes.

Puberty in females involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche).

Effects of Estrogen:

  • Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts and reproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips.
  • Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification, and cervical mucus production, induce closure of the epiphyses.
  • Estrogen has a positive effect in maintaining bone formation and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most abundant plasma protein?
questions.solution:
Albumin is the most abundant protein in the blood and accounts for about 50% of all plasma proteins. 

Serum protein electrophoresis is a method of separation and identification of proteins based on their net charge, size, and shape. The largest peak that lies closest to the positive electrode (left corner) is that of albumin since it is present in the largest proportion in the plasma.

questions.text: Which among the following is not preferred as an analgesic in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Ketorolac is not preferred in rheumatoid arthritis. It is a potent analgesic but a moderately effective anti-inflammatory drug. 

Ketorolac is not administered in chronic painful conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and its use is limited to 5 days or less for acute conditions.

The thyroid gland extends from vertebral levels C5 to T1. This corresponds to A to D in the given image.

questions.text: Which of the following combination of cylindrical lenses can be used to treat with-the-rule astigmatism?
questions.solution:
- 3.00 DC x 180, + 1.00 DC x 90 can be used to correct with-the-rule astigmatism.

In with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is steeper than the horizontal meridian. Hence, to make up for this, we need a combination of cylindrical lenses with relatively greater power in the horizontal meridian than the vertical meridian.

Before considering the options, also remember that a cylinder aligned along the horizontal meridian (180 axis) has action in the vertical meridian and vice versa.

In option A, the cylinder acting along the horizontal meridian (- 3.00 DC x 90) has lesser power than the one acting along the vertical meridian (+ 5.00 DC x 180). This is also the case with options B and C.  

Only option D has a cylinder with greater power along the horizontal meridian ( +1.00 DC x 90) compared to the vertical meridian (- 3.00 DC x 180). Hence, option D is the answer.

 Alternative method:

This method involves the use of the optical cross technique

STEP 1:

  • Frame the optical cross with the given powers in their respective meridians.
  • While framing the optical cross, the power which is given in 180 needs to marked in 90 and vice versa.

For example, option A has + 5.00 DC x 180, - 3.00 DC x 90 which means the eye gets a correction of + 5.00 in vertical meridian (i.e in 90 degree) and correction of - 3.00 in horizontal meridian (i.e in 180 degree). Keeping this in mind, if one frames the optical crosses for the given options, the end image would be as given below  

 

 STEP 2:

Now we need to interpret the optical crosses to find which meridian is steeper with certain hints.

  • If the power in one axis is ‘+’ and the power in other axis is ‘-’, then the axis with ‘-’ power is steeper.
  • If powers in both the axis are ‘-’, then the higher number of the two will be steeper.
  • If powers in both the axis are ‘+’, then the lower number of the two will be steeper.

STEP 3:

Applying these hints to the options will give option D as with-the-rule astigmatism.

questions.text: If the diameter of an artery was found to be reduced to one-third. By what value does the resistance of the artery increase?
questions.solution:
The resistance increases by 81 times.

The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed by the Poiseuille-Hagen formula.

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula: 

Q =π ΔPr4/8ηL

Where

  • Q is the flow rate
  • π is pie symbol
  • ΔP is the pressure difference
  • r is radius
  • η is viscosity
  • L is length

Also,

Flow rate (Q) = pressure difference (ΔP)/ resistance (R).

Therefore, substituting this in Poiseuille- Hagen formula,

ΔP/ R = π ΔPr4/8ηl

1/R = π r4/8ηl

R = 8ηl/ π r4

Therefore it can be derived that airway resistance is inversely proportional to the radius by the power of four.

In the given question, the diameter is reduced to one-third. So, the radius is also reduced to one-third. Hence, vessel resistance will increase by 34 or 81 times.

With Poiseuille- Hagen formula we might feel that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance. However, the contribution by the smallest airways is very little to the overall total resistance. This is because, the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases. (Total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high). Thus the overall resistance of the small airways is very small. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially as the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

Other factors affecting airway resistance :

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the transairway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal infection is most commonly seen in the maxillary sinus?
questions.solution:
Aspergillosis and mucormycosis are the most common fungal infections that involve the maxillary sinuses.

The most common sinus affected by a fungal infection is the maxillary sinus (fungal balls), accounting for approximately 94% of the cases.

questions.text: A  newborn had hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely​ lead to the given condition?
questions.solution:
Treacher Collins syndrome that results from abnormal development of the 1st pharyngeal arch (mandibular arch). 

First arch syndromes are congenital defects caused due to the failure of the neural crest cells to migrate into the 1st pharyngeal arch. 

  • Treacher-Collins syndrome (mandibulo-facial dysostosis) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder seen in 1/50,000 live births. It is characterized by
    • Craniofacial bone defects involving the mandible (causing micrognathia), maxilla, and zygomatic arches
    • Ear defects involving the external ear, atresia of auditory canals, and abnormalities of the middle ear ossicles, leading to bilateral conductive hearing loss
    • Eye defects such as down-slanting palpebral fissures and lower eyelid colobomas
  • Pierre Robin sequence (or Robin sequence) is a deformity seen in 1/8500 births. It may be caused due to genetic defects or due to environmental factors. It can also be seen in oligohydramnios, when the chin gets compressed against the chest in utero. 
    • It is characterized by a triad of micrognathia, glossoptosis (posteriorly placed tongue), and cleft palate.

questions.text: You see a child with delayed speech development as part of a health visit at a local school. The otoscopic appearance of the ear is shown below. Hearing loss of 20 dB is detected in audiometric tests. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image suggest a diagnosis of serous otitis media. 

The golden yellow discoloration of the tympanic membrane is caused by the clear watery straw-colored effusion filling the middle ear. Since the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the middle ear quite clearly on otoscopy.

Patients having serous otitis media will have hearing loss that rarely exceeds 40 dB. This deafness can pass unnoticed, and maybe accidentally discovered during audiometric screening tests. Because of hearing loss, the development of speech is delayed or defective.

Otoscopic findings in serous otitis media:

  • Fluid level and air bubbles are seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.
  • In chronic cases, the fluid becomes very sticky. Hence, the name glue ear. 
  • The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex.
  • The mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) used?
questions.solution:
Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) is useful in congenital external auditory canal atresia.

Bilateral aural atresia presents with failed audiological testing and requires early bone conduction hearing aids, one of which is BAHA, which combines a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear and allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear – a process known as direct bone conduction.

It consists of three parts:

  • An innermost titanium fixture in the bone
  • A middle abutment 
  • An outer hearing aid fixed to the abutment

Bone-anchored Hearing Aids are used:

  • When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    • People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal are associated with discharge and cannot wear standard “in the ear” air-conduction hearing aids.
    • Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals as in microtia or canal atresia.
  • In Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated
  • In single-sided deafness

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of Niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

The lesion in the neck is characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

Other options:

 

B. Zinc: Zinc deficiency can cause various symptoms, but it does not typically present with the specific symptoms described in the case.

C. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine deficiency can lead to a condition called beriberi, which primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system. It does not typically present with skin lesions or diarrhea as described in the case.

D. Iron: Iron deficiency can result in anemia and other symptoms, but it does not cause the specific symptoms described, including skin lesions and diarrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following statements does not apply during cross-examination in a court of law?

choices.text: Witness is examined by the defense lawyer
Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent
There is no time limit to cross examination

questions.solution:
Leading questions are allowed in a cross-examination according to Sec. 143 IEA. However, they are not allowed during the direct examination conducted by the summoning counsel.

In the event that Judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile, leading questions may be allowed during direct examination. 

Leading questions (Sec. 141 IEA) are defined as questions that suggest an answer that is favorable for the case of the summoning counsel or in alignment with their claim. 

Other options:

Options 1, 3, 4 - In cross-examination, the witness is examined by the defense lawyer or adverse party with an objective to elicit favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and also, to discredit the witness. 

While leading questions are allowed in cross-examination, the Judge can disallow questions that are indecent (Sec. 151 IEA) or questions asked with an intention to insult,  or offend the witness in any form (Sec. 152 IEA).

There is no time limit to the duration of cross-examination. 

 

The sequence of examination in the recording of evidence is as follows -

Sequence of examination Objective
  • Examination-in-Chief/Direct examination by the party that summoned the witness

To elicit the facts of the case from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed.
  • Cross-examination by the defense lawyer
 To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness. Leading questions are allowed.
  • Re-examination by the party that summoned the witness
 To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective

questions.text: Which among the following aids in supination and pronation of the forearm?
questions.solution:
Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints

Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination of the affected eye, a relative afferent pupillary defect with a normal optic disc is seen. Visual field testing was done which revealed central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes, RAPD and central scotoma is suggestive of optic neuritis, specifically retrobulbar neuritis. 

There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The common causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease).

Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss.  Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. 

On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noted due to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal scotoma. 

Type Retrobulbar neuritis Papillitis Neuroretinitis
Pathology Inflammation of the optic nerve behind the disc Inflammation of the optic nerve head  Inflammation of the optic nerve head and the macula
Fundus appearance Optic disc appears normal

Hyperemia and oedema of the optic disc with or without peri-papillary flame-shaped hemorrhages

 Macular star (due to exudates that form around macula)
Prevalence Most common in adults

Most common in children

 Least common type
Associated conditions Strong association with demyelinating disorders like MS, NMO

Weak association with demyelinating disorders

 Cat-scratch disease, Lyme disease, Syphilis etc.

 

The image below shows papillitis.

 

The image below shows macular star appearance in neuroretinitis.

Causes of RAPD:

  • Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
  • Maculopathy (macular degeneration )
  • Optic nerve lesions (e.g., optic neuritis, retrobulbar neuritis in multiple sclerosis , anterior ischemic optic neuropathy , glaucoma)
  • Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)

Causes of central/centrocaecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion eg. Pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
  • Poor nutrition
  • Tobacco
  • Alcohol
  • Drug- induced optic neuropathy
  • Toxin- induced optic neuropathy
  • Hereditary optic atrophy
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leukemia

questions.text: What is the level of prevention when a person receives penicillin injections for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease?
questions.solution:
Receiving penicillin injections for the treatment of rheumatic heart disease is Secondary prevention.

Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.

Levels of Prevention : 

1. Primordial prevention:

  • Involves the prevention of the emergence or development of risk factors in countries or population groups in which they have not yet appeared.
  • Examples include adult health problems like obesity and hypertension, which have an early onset due to lifestyles like smoking, eating patterns and physical exercise, which are discouraged from early childhood
  • The main intervention in primordial prevention is through individual and mass education.

2. Primary prevention:

  • These are defined as "action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur''
  • It signifies intervention in the pre-pathogenesis phase of a disease or health problem
  • Primary prevention is accomplished by measures promoting general health and well-being, and the quality of life of people by specific protective measures.
  • They include two strategies:
  • Population (mass) strategy: Where the target group is the whole population
  • High-risk strategy: Where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease
  • Examples: immunity, sanitation, and protection of food.

3. Secondary prevention :

  • This is defined as "action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications.".
  • The specific interventions are early diagnoses like screening tests and adequate treatment.
  • The main aim of secondary prevention is to arrest the disease process.
  • Secondary prevention is largely the domain of clinical medicine and health programs initiated by governments.
  • It is an imperfect tool in the control of the transmission of disease. It is often more expensive and less effective than primary prevention.

4. Tertiary prevention :

  • Measures to reduce the duration of mental illness and family and community stresses to prevent further breakdown and disruption.
  • Disability limitation belongs to tertiary prevention.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention
