questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of macrocytic anemia?
questions.solution:
Alcohol is the most common cause of macrocytic anaemia. 

Macrocytic anemia can be megaloblastic anemia and non-megaloblastic anemia. Alcohol causes non megaloblastic macrocytic anemia. 

Other causes of macrocytic anaemia: 

  • Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
  • Bone marrow disorders 
  • Liver disease 
  • Drug-induced 
  • HIV 
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Complication of bariatric surgery 

Megaloblastic anemia is a type of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation. The causes include:

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Folate deficiency
  • Drugs (Methotrexate)

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Other causes of B12 deficiency includes

  • Malabsorption (Pernicious anemia)
  • Total or partial gastrectomy
  • Ileal resection
  • Tropical sprue

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (SACDSC). Seen in only B12 deficiency.
  • Psychiatric disturbances

questions.text: If a wide range of values are present in a community, what is the best measure of central tendency?
questions.solution:
The best measure of central tendency if there are a wide range of values is median.

If we take an example of a dataset of (1, 1, 1, 2, 4, 5, 5, 5, 6, 11, 41), we can see that 41 seems to be well away from the mean of 7.45 of the dataset.  If we eliminate this outlier, we can get a new dataset of (1, 1, 1, 2, 4, 5, 5, 5, 6, 11) with a median of 4.5 and a mean of 4.1. We see that the median only changed by 10% (went down to 4.5 from 5), while the mean decreased by 45%. Therefore, the median is less affected by outliers or extreme values.

 The median is not sensitive to extreme values or outliers and thus it is the preferred measure of central tendency in a distribution with a wide range of values.

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen. It exists as trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, directly through traumatized skin or eyes, or ingestion of cysts.

It chiefly presents as two chronic conditions:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis

Acanthamoeba keratitis is an infection of the eyes that typically develops from the entry of the amebic cyst through abrasions on the cornea. Most of the cases are associated with the use of contact lenses. 

Patients usually present with photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and foreign body sensation and it can be bilateral in contact lens users.

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The cysts are smaller (12-25 μm) and polygonal or star-shaped.

Topical administration of biguanides or chlorhexidine with or without diamidine agents can be used for the management of acanthamoeba keratitis. In severe cases penetrating keratoplasty can be done.

The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

 

The below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.

Other options:

Option B- Naegleria fowleri causes a brain infection, primary amebic meningoencephalitis that leads to brain tissue destruction. Their cysts are spherical and have a smooth double wall. 

Option C- Entamoeba histolytica causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Their cysts are spherical in shape. A mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form.  An amebic ulcer is a typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis which is a flask-shaped ulcer in cross-section. Amebic liver abscess is extraintestinal amebiasis which has a center of abscess that contains thick colored brown pus termed anchovy sauce pus.

Option D- Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living ameba that causes granulomatous amebic encephalitis. Their cyst is usually spherical and surrounded by a three-layered cyst wall.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about a PHC except

choices.text: There is 1 PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas
Type A PHC conducts < 20 deliveries per month.
Provides maternal and child health care, family planning and MTP

questions.solution:
A PHC is not a first referral unit (FRU). FRUs are centres that provide round-the-clock services for emergency obstetric and newborn care and manage emergencies that any well-equipped hospital is required to provide. CHCs, district hospitals, sub-divisional hospitals, etc. are FRUs.

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

    • Type B: PHC with 20 or more deliveries per month.
  • Functions:
    • Medical care: OPD, emergencies, referrals and in-patient services.
    • Maternal and child health care, family planning and MTP
    • Health education
    • Nutrition services: malnutrition, vitamin A deficiency, anemia.
    • School and adolescent health services
    • Prevention and control of locally endemic diseases
    • Recording, collection, and reporting of vital events
    • Promotion of sanitation and testing of water
    • National health programme functions
    • Referral services
    • Training of health workers, ASHAs, ANMs, etc.
    • Basic laboratory services
    • Monitoring and supervising activities
    • Selected surgical procedures
    • Mainstreaming AYUSH and PMR

questions.text: Carotid body chemoreceptors are stimulated by all of the following types of hypoxia except_____
questions.solution:
Anemic hypoxia does not stimulate carotid body chemoreceptors.

In anemia,

  • Amount of dissolved O2 reaching the receptors is generally normal 
  • Combined O2 in the blood is markedly decreased.
  • The blood flow per unit tissue of carotid body chemoreceptors is enormous (2000mL/100g of tissue/min). Hence, O2 needs of the tissue can be met largely by dissolved O2 alone. Therefore, the receptors are not stimulated by conditions such as anemia or carbon monoxide poisoning, in which the amount of dissolved O2 reaching the receptors is generally normal, even though combined O2 in the blood is markedly decreased. These peripheral chemoreceptors are stimulated when arterial pO2 is low.

questions.text: A 55 yr old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of having a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from ________
questions.solution:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. Liver microscopy shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's prussian blue stain.

Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The characteristic triad of hemochromatosis includes:

  1. Micronodular cirrhosis
  2. Diabetes mellitus in 75% to 80% of patients
  3. Abnormal skin pigmentation in 75% to 80% of patients

Note: The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.

questions.text: A 40 year old female with no comorbidities complaints of swelling in  both her legs which was acute in onset . She also gives a history of loose stools. Her family members too has similar symptoms. On examination there was no signs of inflammation in both the legs. Detailed history revealed that mustard oil is a staple part of their diet . Which of the following substance is responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is suggestive of epidemic dropsy and Sanguinarine is the toxic compound responsible for this.

Epidemic Dropsy: Contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil.

  • Toxic compound: Sanguinarine 
  • Mechanism of action : Sanguinarine interfers with the oxidation of pyruvic acid which inturn accumulates in the blood and causes symptoms.
  • Clinical presentation :The patient presents with sudden onset, non inflammatory swelling of bilateral legs which is often associated with diarrhoea. Some patients can develop glaucoma. Dyspnea, cardiac failure and death can occur in later stages.
  • Mortality rate - 5-50%  

Tests to detect argemone oil:

  • Nitric acid test
  • Paper chromatography: most sensitive(can detect very low concentration of argemone oil)

Toxic Principles Of Various Diseases

Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine 
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids

questions.text: A patient has significant distress on reading text off paper or screen. On examination of his eyes, all domains including visual acuity are essentially normal except for Schirmer's test which reads 5mm. What is the best way to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is most likely to be one of dry eye or keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS). The best initial management would be to lubricate the eye. 

Treatment of dry eye includes medical treatment (lubricating eyedrops, most commonly methylcellulose derivatives) or surgical treatment (lacrimal punctum occlusion using silicone plugs).

The tests used to diagnose dry eye (KCS) are:

1. Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

2. Tear film break-up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

3. Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

4. Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: A health care worker has been found to be seropositive for HBsAg, HBeAg, and Anti-HBc: IgM, indicating an acute HBV infection with high infectivity. Liver biopsy in such cases is likely to show all of the following, except________.
questions.solution:
Ground-glass hepatocytes are not seen in acute hepatitis.

“Ground-glass” hepatocytes—cells with endoplasmic reticulum swollen by HBsAg—is a diagnostic hallmark in chronic hepatitis B.

The below image shows ground glass hepatocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

The straight sinus is a continuation of the inferior sagittal sinus. It lies in the junction of the falx cerebri with tentorium cerebelli. The straight sinus further drains into one of the transverse sinuses (mostly the left).

questions.text: Which among the following is not routinely screened before conducting a blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Blood transfusion does not require routine screening of donor blood for hepatitis A infection.

Some of the transfusion-transmitted infections routinely tested are:

  • Hepatitis C virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  • Hepatitis B virus

Transfusion-transmitted diseases currently not routinely tested are:

  • Hepatitis A virus
  • Hepatitis E virus
  • Parvovirus B19
  • Dengue fever virus
  • Malaria
  • Zika virus

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. On examination, the right ear reveals conductive hearing loss with a dull tympanic membrane. A decreased mobility of the soft palate was also noted. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking. The commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common)
  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
      • CN VI - squint and diplopia, the most common cranial nerve involved
      • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
      • CN V - reduced corneal reflex (Option B)
      • CN II - exophthalmos (Option D)
      • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
      • Horner’s syndrome
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathological image of the growth is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis.

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutter and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which breaks down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of Foot.

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics.

Phaeohyphomycosis : it is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions maybe plaques which are verrucous, hypertkeratotis or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other demetacious fungi.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with bleeding gums for 20 days. He has gingival hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. On investigation, Hb - 11 g/dL, platelet count -  95,000 platelets/mm3, and WBC count - 45000 cells/mm3. Bone marrow biopsy shows 100% cellularity with many blast cells that are peroxidase negative and non-specific esterase positive.  The most likely diagnosis is _____.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis from the clinical presentation and cytochemistry is acute myeloid leukemia (AML) M5 or acute monocytic leukemia.

Diagnostic features of AML M5:  20% or more blasts in the bone marrow. Markedly elevated white blood cell count with organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, CNS involvement and other tissue infiltration. Monoblasts have folded or lobulated nuclei, lack Auer rods, and are nonspecific esterase positive. Classified as AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities such as inv(16)(p13;1q22), t(16;16)(p13.1q22) or t(9;11)(p22;q23) 

Note:

Myeloperoxidase is present in the azurophilic granules of neutrophils and its precursors. It is positive in AML M1, M2, M3, M4 and negative in AML M0. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive. When positive, the granules are smaller than in neutrophils and diffusely scattered throughout the cytoplasm.

 

Image: Bone marrow aspirate in AML M5

questions.text: Which of the following is used to estimate relative risk (RR)?
questions.solution:
Relative risk is best estimated in cohort studies.

Relative Risk:

  • The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called the risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR >1 indicates a positive association.
  • RR of 2 or higher indicates a >/=100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ c/(c+d)] where, 
  Disease
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

questions.text: A man regularly derives sexual gratification by inflicting pain upon his partner. He would often produce cuts and cigarette burns on his partner's arms. This is best described as?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of sexual sadism. It is seen more commonly in men. It develops due to early experiences of brutality in sex.

The sadist may bite, beat, whip, produce cuts or cigarette burns etc on their sexual partner. In extreme cases, the victim's nipples may be bitten off, items such as a bottle or sticks are inserted into the vagina. Blunt trauma causing fractures and rupture of internal organs may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Voyeurism: it is the act of obtaining sexual gratification by observing an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing or engaging in sexual activity.

Option B - Fetishism: it is a form of sexual behaviour in which gratification is associated with an abnormal stimulus which may be an object, activity or part of the body.

Option D - Masochism: this is opposite to sadism. Sexual gratification is obtained by suffering the pain.

questions.text: State the action of the muscle marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the given image is supraspinatus and the action of the muscle is abduction of the shoulder joint. It steadies the head of the humerus during movements, and abducts the shoulder joint from 0-15°

Supraspinatus is a part of the rotator interval, an area between the superior edge of the subscapularis and the anterior edge of supraspinatus with the coracoid as the medial boundary of the interval.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix appeared strawberry-like. Which of the following statements is false regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: It exists in cyst and trophozoite form
The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM or PEM
The treatment of choice is metronidazole

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection.

Trichomonas vaginalis is the only protozoa with one stage in its life cycle ie., trophozoite form (No cyst stage is seen).

It is an obligate parasite and cannot live without close association with vaginal, urethral, or prostatic tissues. Sexual transmission is the main route of infection. 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of mobility on the wet saline mount.

The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on CPLM (cystine-peptone-liver infusion-maltose) or PEM.

The treatment of choice  is the oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days.

questions.text: You are working as an internal medicine consultant at a private clinic. A patient with chronic renal disease requiring hemodialysis is admitted under you. You advise diet and fluid control and keep him under observation. However, the patient progresses to take ayurvedic supplements and sometimes skips the your instructions without disclosing it. His conditions worsen and he develops difficulty in breathing. His attendant files a complaint in court alleging the negligence of the doctor. Which of the following acts as a defence for the doctor in court?
questions.solution:
In the given case, since the patient did not adhere to the proper instructions of the doctor, it was partly or wholly his fault. This is termed contributory negligence. Proper documentation as to how ordinary care was not exercised on part of the patient can be useful in a court of law.

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred

Other options:

Option A: Vicarious liability is not a defence against professional negligence. Vicarious liability (liability for the actions of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees.

Option B: Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself'. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on part of the doctor eg: leaving behind a scalpel or scissor whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C: Therapeutic misadventure may serve as a defence against negligence. It basically refers to an adverse outcome that could not have been anticipated despite reasonable care. eg: a rare side effect of a drug or blood loss due to an anomalous artery despite exercising caution.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A primipara is being evaluated for hearing impairment which had worsened during her pregnancy. Rinne’s test is negative in both ears and Weber’s test is lateralized to the right side. On otoscopy, tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry shows a dip in BC at 2000 Hz. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the treatment of choice for otosclerosis is stapedotomy.

Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. This is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

Stapedectomy is the excision of the entire stapes (superstructure + footplate) and placing a piston in its place. It is outdated.

Sodium fluoride (NaF) is used in an active case of otosclerosis to hasten maturation.

Note: 

  • Both stapedectomy and stapedotomy have been described for the treatment of otosclerosis. Even in the stapedectomy procedure, stapedotomy (drilling) has been practiced. Hence stapedotomy is preferred over stapedectomy and is considered the treatment of choice.
  • In the above case since Rinne’s test is negative on both ears, it indicates bilateral conductive deafness. Weber’s test will lateralize to the ear with greater conductive loss.

questions.text: A patient has presented with blister on hand followed by axillary lymphadenopathy. What will you ask the patient with regard to history?

choices.text: History of similar complaint in family members

questions.solution:
Patient with blister on the hand followed by axillary lymphadenopathy is more suggestive of Cat scratch disease, a disease caused by Bartonella henselae, hence we should ask about the history of exposure to cat.

Cat-scratch disease is also known as subacute regional lymphadenitis. It is acquired following contact with infected animals, commonly cats. 

Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:

  • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
  • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
  • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells
  • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

Bartonella henselae also causes bacillary angiomatosis and bacillary peliosis in HIV-infected people.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical structure marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image is extensor pollicis longus. 

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or "snuff."

Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: 

Lateral wall:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL),
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  

Medial wall:

  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL).

Roof:

  • Cephalic vein
  • Sup. Br of radial nerve

Floor:

  • Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium and 1st Metacarpal. 

Only content: Radial artery

questions.text: A child on workup is found to be suffering from a rare form of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency for which he has developed high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the best dietary advice for the patient?

choices.text: High protein and low carbohydrate intake
High carbohydrate and low fat intake
High fat and low carbohydrate intake

questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency(PDH) can be due to a defect in any one/more of the components of the PDH enzyme complex. Patients are advised to follow a high fat and low carbohydrate intake.

In pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, there is a defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex, leading to impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This results in the accumulation of pyruvate and subsequent conversion to lactate, causing lactic acidosis and high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

To provide an alternative fuel source for the body, patients with pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency are often advised to follow a high-fat and low-carbohydrate diet. By reducing the intake of carbohydrates, which are metabolized to pyruvate, and increasing the intake of fats, which can be metabolized via alternative pathways, the reliance on the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex can be minimized.

Therefore, option C (High fat and low carbohydrate intake) is the most appropriate dietary advice for a patient with pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency and high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Other options:

Option A: High protein and low carbohydrate intake - This option is incorrect because a high protein intake would still involve the metabolism of amino acids, which can contribute to the production of pyruvate and further exacerbate the metabolic acidosis in pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency. 

Option B: High carbohydrate and low-fat intake - This option is incorrect because pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency impairs the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, resulting in the accumulation of pyruvate and subsequent lactic acidosis. 

Option D: Only carbohydrate intake henceforth - This option is incorrect because pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency specifically affects the metabolism of carbohydrates, leading to the accumulation of pyruvate. Relying solely on carbohydrate intake would exacerbate the metabolic acidosis by increasing pyruvate levels.

questions.text: Which among the following methods is used to sterilize a glass petri dish?

choices.text: Autoclaving at 121 degree Celsius for 30 – 60 minutes
Hot air oven at 160 degree Celsius for 120 minutes or less
Flash autoclaving at 134 degree Celsius for 3 minutes
Hot air oven at 121 degrees Celsius for 30 – 60 minutes

questions.solution:
Hot air oven at 160 degree Celsius for 2 hours is used to sterilize glasswares like petri dish.

Exposure to dry heat in a sterilizing hot air oven at temperatures of 160° Celsius for 2 hours ensures carbonization of organic material and destruction of microorganisms and spores.

  • This method can be used for metals, glassware, some heat-resistant and/or water-immiscible oils, powders and waxes.
  • One of the drawback of  sterilization with hot air is that it has no penetrating power, and hence not suitable for disinfection of bulky articles such as mattresses.
  • Because it employs very high temperatures it destroys plastic, rubber and other delicate substances.

Related Pearl: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses
1. Heat    
Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings
Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth 
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books
3. Radiation    
UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets
Ionising All Surgical supplies, food
4. Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: There are 30 people at a small camping site. How will they best manage their refuse disposal?
questions.solution:
Burial is suitable for refuse (municipal, nonhazardous solid waste) in small camps.

Other methods of refuse disposal:

  • Dumping: Refuse is dumped into low lying areas by throwing it in open space.
  • Incineration: It is the method of choice of disposal by burning when suitable land is not available.
  • Composting:
    • This is a method of combined disposal of refuse and sludge.
    • Compost has manorial value for soil.
    • It includes 2 methods:
      • Bangalore method - Anaerobic composting
      • Indore method - Aerobic mechanical composting
  • Controlled tipping (sanitary landfill): It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. The material is placed in a trench or other prepared area, adequately compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the working day. There are three methods under controlled tipping:
    1. The trench method
    2. The ramp method
    3. The area method
  • Manure pits: Commonly used in rural areas in India.

questions.text: Insulin acts on glucose metabolism by______

choices.text: ↓ permeability of glucose across cell membrane
↑ reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules

questions.solution:
Insulin stimulates the entry of glucose into cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane.

This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues.

questions.text: The X-Ray of a middle aged man showed multiple lytic lesions following which a urine examination was done. The sample revealed Bence Jones proteins. Which is the most common immunoglobulin associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario consisting of multiple lytic bony lesions and Bence Jones proteins indicates multiple myeloma.  Most myelomas are associated with more than 3 g/dL of serum Ig and/or more than 6 mg/dL of urine Bence Jones protein. The most common monoclonal Immunoglobulin (M protein) is IgG followed by IgA.

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors involving the axial skeleton. The bones most commonly affected in descending order of frequency are the vertebral column, ribs, skull, pelvis, femur, clavicle, and scapula. 

Morphology:

  • Malignant plasma cells have a perinuclear clearing due to a prominent golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus.
  • Relatively normal-appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.
  • Other cytologic variants include flame cells, Mott cells.
  • Flame cells have fiery red cytoplasm, Mott cells contain multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets, a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules. The globular inclusions are referred to as Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).
  • Rouleaux formation is characteristic but not specific. High levels of M protein in the blood causes red cells to stick to one another in linear arrays in smears leading to rouleaux formation.

Image showing peripheral smear of multiple myeloma:

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

  • Serum β2-microglobulin. It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17pITP53 sequences and the translocations t(14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

The clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma can be done based on the identification of clonal plasma cells in the marrow and the presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions).

Other options:

A) Ig A is not the most common immunoglobulin associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. While Ig A can be involved in some cases, Ig G is the most frequently observed immunoglobulin in this context.

B) Ig D is not commonly associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. Bence Jones proteins are typically composed of monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains, and Ig D is not commonly involved in plasma cell disorders such as multiple myeloma.

D) Ig M is not the most common immunoglobulin associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. While Ig M can be involved in certain plasma cell disorders, Ig G is the most frequently observed immunoglobulin associated with Bence Jones proteins.

Related Pearl: International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: What is the affinity of carbon monoxide to hemoglobin in comparison to oxygen?
questions.solution:
CO binds to hemoglobin with an affinity that is 250 times that of O2 to form carboxyhemoglobin. 

CO also increases the O2 affinity of remaining free hemoglobin sites (causes left shift of the O2 - hemoglobin dissociation curve).

  • Curve A - Myoglobin O2-dissociation curve
  • Curve B - Normal Hb O2-dissociation curve
  • Curve C- CO binds to hemoglobin and prevents O2 binding
  • Curve D - Anemia

Carbon monoxide (CO) reacts with hemoglobin to form carbon monoxyhemoglobin (carboxyhemoglobin or COHb). The affinity of hemoglobin for CO is 210 times its affinity for O2, and COHb liberates CO very slowly. An additional difficulty is that when COHb is present, the dissociation curve of the remaining HbO2 shifts to the left, decreasing the amount of O2 released.

Treatment of CO poisoning consists of ventilation with oxygen since oxygen hastens the dissociation of carboxyhemoglobin.

questions.text: Which among the following is a short-acting beta blocker?
questions.solution:
Esmolol is a short-acting cardioselective beta blocker that is indicated in:

  • Prevention and management of intraoperative tachycardia/hypertension
  • Supraventricular tachycardia
  • Hypertensive emergency

Nadolol and atenolol are long-acting beta-blockers and propranolol is a non-selective beta blocker with an intermediate duration of action. 

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: A patient presents with a hard painless nodule on the upper eyelid. It was observed to be growing outwards, away from the lid margin. What could be the most probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of a chalazion (tarsal cyst/meibomian cyst). It has the malignant potential to become an adenocarcinoma of the meibomian gland. 

It is the chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland. It presents as painless swelling of the eyelid. It is more common in adults than children. Treatment includes incision and curettage and intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetate.

Other options:

  • Hordeolum externum or stye is the suppurative inflammation of the gland of Zeis. It is hard and painful, and there is a visible pus point on the lid margin. 
  • Entropion refers to the inward rolling and rotation of the lid margin towards the globe. It is more common in the lower lid
  • Loss of eyelashes is seen in chronic blepharitis.

questions.text: Testosterone is converted to which of the following hormone by aromatase enzyme?
questions.solution: Aromatase (CYP19) converts testosterone to estradiol.

questions.text: The number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births is called ___.
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality ratio is defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births during a given time period.

Other options:

Infant mortality rate (IMR) is defined as the ratio of infant deaths registered in a given year to the total number of live births in the same year.

Maternal mortality rate is the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age in a given time period.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

  • Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.
  • MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period
  • Main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia related complications, etc.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: A woman presented with sudden onset of dysphagia, dysarthria and gait ataxia. MRI revealed an acute infarct in the right dorsolateral medulla. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wallenberg syndrome. The symptoms of dysphagia and dysarthria are due to the involvement of nucleus ambiguus. Ataxia is a feature of inferior cerebellar peduncle involvement.

Option A: Medial medullary syndrome is also known as Dejerine's anterior bulbar syndrome.

Option B: Lateral medullary syndrome is also known as Wallenberg syndrome.

Option C: Medullary tegmental paralysis is also known as Babinski-Nageotte syndrome.

Option D: Midbrain stroke syndrome is also known as Weber syndrome.
