questions.text: A patient with a history of road traffic accident is brought to the emergency room with retroperitoneal bleed. Trauma to which of the following structures is the most likely the cause of this bleed?
questions.solution:
The pancreas is the most likely cause as it is a retroperitoneal structure. All the other structures listed are intraperitoneal.

Relationship of viscera to the peritoneum:

  • Intraperitoneal: Stomach, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, transverse colon, sigmoid colon, liver, gall bladder, and spleen.
  • Retroperitoneal: Esophagus (abdominal), duodenum (2nd and 3rd segment), pancreas, kidneys, ureters, suprarenal glands, abdominal aorta and its branches, inferior vena cava, and celiac plexus.
  • Partially covered in the peritoneum (also considered as retroperitoneal): Ascending colon, descending colon, and rectum.

questions.text: What is this view called in which frontal sinus is seen best ?
questions.solution:
Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position):

The view is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally, as shown in the image above. Structures seen with Caldwell's view are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best).
  • Ethmoid sinuses.
  • Maxillary sinuses.
  • Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone.
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea.
  • Superior orbital fissure.
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: Which of the following cannot utilize ketone bodies?
questions.solution:
RBCs and the liver cannot utilize ketone bodies.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria.

The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme CoA transferase (thiophorase).

questions.text: Which amongst the following can be used to treat kesari dal toxicity?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000 mg can be used for the prevention and treatment of lathyrism (kesari dal toxicity).

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal or Lathyrus sativus. When the husk is removed, it looks similar to red gram or Bengal gram. It is mostly consumed by poor agricultural laborers because it is relatively cheap. Lathyrism is more prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Odisha, and Bihar. The Prevention of Food Adulteration Act in India has banned Lathyrus sativus in all forms (whole/ split/ flour). 

In humans, it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system. It is characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) is the toxic compound causing this disease. It is water-soluble and can be removed by the following methods:

  • Soaking pulses in hot water and discarding the water 
  • Overnight soaking in lime water, followed by boiling 
  • Parboiling - for large-scale detoxification

questions.text: A 5 year old presents with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that the child is suffering from respiratory papillomatosis.

Respiratory papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis )

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. 
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx .
  • C/F
    • Age 3–5 years
    • Hoarseness or aphonia
    • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. 
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser Excision.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of recurrent, large-volume, watery diarrhea. She reports experiencing multiple episodes per day, often waking her at night. She has also noted significant weight loss and episodes of muscle weakness. Laboratory findings reveal hypokalemia. Imaging studies of the abdomen show a mass in the tail of the pancreas. Which pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent, large-volume, watery diarrhea with laboratory evidence of hypokalemia and a mass in the pancreatic tail is most likely afflicted by a VIPoma.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumours (VIPomas) are  pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours that secrete excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptides (VIP) which are responsible for the secretory watery diarrhoea and other symptoms. The patient commonly presents with severe intermittent watery diarrhoea leading to dehydration, and weakness from fluid and electrolyte losses.

Electrolyte abnormalities in VIPoma include:

  • Metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia- due to a large amount of GI loss and bicarbonate wasting
  • Hypochlorhydria- due to the direct gastric acid inhibitory effect of VIP
  • Hypomagnesemia- due to severe diarrhoea
  • Hyperglycemia- due to the increased glycogenolytic activity of VIP
  • Hypercalcemia- due to dehydration, coincidental MEN1 syndrome, or secretion by the tumor of a calcitrophic peptide

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumor (VIPoma) is also referred to as Verner–Morrison syndrome/ WDHA syndrome:

WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

Metastases commonly occurs in the liver, lymph nodes, bones, and kidney.

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level (upto 250 to 500 pg/ml) and a history of large-volume diarrhea (> 5L/day). A CT scan localizes most VIPomas. EUS is the most sensitive imaging method.

While suspecting a case of VIPoma it is essential to conduct a VIP assay so as to confirm the presence of other tumors of neural crest origin such as neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma. 

The medical management of VIPoma:

  • Initial medical management is symptomatic with correction of fluids and electrolyte imbalance. 
  • Somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide inhibit secretion of VIP and are used for symptomatic control.
  • Glucocorticoids are used in patients refractory to somatostatin analogs.
  • Interferon-alpha has also been used in patients in patients not responding to the above medications.

The surgical management of VIPoma:

  • Complete resection is the treatment of choice for primary tumors and is usually a distal pancreatectomy. If the tumor cannot be excised completely, surgical debulkingmay be done 
  • Radiofrequency ablation and cryoablation
  • Hepatic artery embolization is a palliative treatment measure in patients with unresectable hepatic metastases.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Syndrome

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms
  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: An underweight adolescent girl is found to have the following finding on her ocular examination. What is the WHO grade for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Bitot spot which is a feature seen in vitamin A deficiency. According to the WHO grading of xerophthalmia, Bitot spots are classified as 1B.

Bitos spots are triangular, pearly-white or yellowish, foamy spots on the bulbar conjunctiva on either side of the cornea.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain abdomen, diarrhea, and a stepladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise. His symptoms were gradually worsening over the past 2 weeks. Which of the following is the best screening test?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of typhoid fever and the best test to screen for a patient symptomatic for 2 weeks is the Widal test.

Enteric fever (typhoid fever) is caused by Salmonella species. The patient presents with stepladder pyrexia (fever), abdominal pain, diarrhea, headache, and malaise.

Diagnosis of enteric fever:

  • Blood culture: It is more sensitive during 1st week than in the subsequent weeks. It rapidly becomes negative on treatment with antibiotics.

  • Antibody testing: WIDAL test to detect rising titers of H and O agglutinins against salmonella typhi and paratyphi. Agglutinins appear by the end of the first week and rise steadily up to the 3rd or 4th week, after which they disappear.

  • Stool culture: It yields positive results from the 3rd week onwards.

  • Urine culture: Results may be positive after the 2nd week.

  • Bone marrow culture remains positive for 5 days even after the start of antibiotics and is the most sensitive test in the first week. The culture of duodenal aspirate may yield positive results when bone marrow culture is inconclusive.
Widal Test: This is a test for the measurement of H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's serum. In this test, the agglutination titer depends on the stage of the disease. It is performed by mixing equal volumes (0.4 ml) of serial dilutions of the serum (from 1/10 to 1/640) with fixed volumes of H and O antigens in the Dreyer's and Felix agglutination tubes, respectively. These tubes are incubated overnight and the agglutination titres are read. H agglutination leads to the formation of cotton woolly clumps while O agglutination is seen as a disc-like pattern at the bottom of the tube.
The antigens used in Widal's test include:
  • O antigens of S. typhi (TO)
  • H antigens of S. typhi (TH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH)

Interpretation: 

  • The agglutination titer will depend on the stage of the disease:
    • Agglutinins usually appear by the end of the first week. 
    • The titer increases steadily till the third or fourth week, after which it declines gradually.
  • The H agglutinins persist longer than O agglutinins.
    • H antibodies appear earliest after infection and persist for several months.
    • The O antibodies follow the appearance of H antibodies and disappear in a few weeks. 
  • The 4-fold rise in titers between 1st and 3rd week is highly significant as compared to a single high titer:
    • This is because, in persons who had a prior enteric fever, there is a transient rise of titer due to unrelated infections (malaria, dengue), known as an anamnestic reaction.
    • Therefore, after a one-week interval, if the titer increases, it indicates true infection. If the titer decreases, it indicates an anamnestic reaction. 
  • Cases treated early with antibiotics may show poor agglutinin response.
  • Interpretation of Widal test: 
    • Demonstration of a rise in titre of antibodies by testing two or more serum samples is more meaningful than a single test.
    • H agglutinin titer > 1/160 and O agglutinin titer >1/80 is considered significant.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to differentiate human blood from the blood of other species?
questions.solution:
The test used to differentiate human blood from the blood of other species is the precipitin test. Specific antiserum is made to react with the seminal fluid, blood or saliva. Precipitin test is used for species identification of semen, blood, or saliva, and a positive test confirms human origin. The precipitin test identifies the presence of proteins that are found only in human blood.

Other options: 

Teichmann test and Takayama test (Options A and D) are used to confirm the presence of blood but cannot be used for species identification of blood.

Barberio test (Option C) is used for the detection of spermatic fluid. 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with a pterygium that has been steadily progressing towards the pupillary area. What is the best means of management in this case?
questions.solution:
The best mode of management in the given options for progressive pterygium is excision with conjunctival autograft.

A pterygium is a degenerative subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory. Histologically, it comprises elastotic degenerative changes in vascularised subepithelial stromal collagen. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye. It is made up of three parts:

  • cap (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge)
  • head
  • body

Patients may be asymptomatic or present with irritation, grittiness, or episodes of inflammation. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism.

Treatment: 

  • A pterygium is best left alone unless:
    • It is progressing towards the pupillary area
    • Causes excessive astigmatism
    • Restricts ocular motility
    • Causes disfigurement.
  • Excision: Simple excision of the pterygium is associated with a high recurrence rate, and should be combined with:
    • Mitomycin C drops- applied pre-operatively/ intra-operatively or post-operatively to prevent a recurrence. However, it may lead to complications like scleral necrosis, cataract, and iritis and should be used judiciously. 
    • Beta-radiation applied postoperatively to the pterygium base was popular for many years, but is associated with late scleral necrosis.
    • Conjunctival autografting- limbal tissue from the same or other eye is grafted and secured with fibrin glue or sutures.
    • Amniotic membrane graft
    • Peripheral lamellar keratoplasty if the lesion is deep.

Currently, the most widely used techniques are conjunctival autografting, amniotic membrane transplantation, and mitomycin-C application either preoperatively or postoperatively (can be applied intraoperatively also) of which conjunctival autografting has fewer recurrence rates and is a simple and quick procedure which reduces the risk of granuloma formation, scleral thinning and necrosis.

Note:

A combination of conjunctival autografting with intraoperative mitomycin C is the most preferred as it has the least recurrence rates as per studies.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be released from the hypothalamus?
questions.solution:
Hexokinase type IV/ glucokinase is most likely to be released from the hypothalamus (ventromedial hypothalamus) 

Glucokinase, also known as hexokinase IV, catalyses the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, which constitutes the first step of glycolysis.

The hypothalamus is an important centre for the regulation of glucose homeostasis. It contains glucokinase/hexokinase IV which plays a central role in the counterregulatory response, which is a feedback system to counteract hypoglycemia by increasing the production of glucose and limiting its utilization.

There are four isoforms of hexokinase: 

  • Hexokinase type I: major isoform in the brain but also ubiquitously expressed
  • Hexokinase type II: predominant in insulin-sensitive tissues such as adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, and cardiac muscle. 
  • Hexokinase type III: not predominant in any tissue.
  • Hexokinase type IV: primarily in the liver, pancreas, hypothalamus, small intestine and other neuroendocrine tissue.

questions.text: Potassium is maximally absorbed in____
questions.solution:
Potassium is maximally absorbed in PCT. 

Potassium is freely filtered by the glomerulus. The bulk of filtered K+ is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. In the proximal tubule, K+ absorption is primarily passive and proportional to Na+ and water through paracellular transport. 

K+ reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of Henle occurs through both transcellular (Na+- K+- 2Cl- cotransport) and paracellular pathways.

K+ secretion begins in the early distal convoluted tubule and progressively increases along the distal nephron into the cortical collecting duct . Most urinary K+ can be accounted for by K+ secretion mediated by principal cells. Under conditions of K+ depletion, reabsorption of K+ occurs in the collecting duct. 

It is the only electrolyte to be reabsorbed as well as secreted.

Related Pearl: Summary of Transport Across Proximal and Distal Portions of the Nephron

Proximal Tubule
Reabsorption

Secretion 

67% of filtered Na+ actively reabsorbed, not subject to control; Cl– follows passively

All filtered glucose and amino acids reabsorbed by secondary active transport; not subject to control

Variable amounts of filtered PO43- and other electrolytes reabsorbed; subject to control

65% of filtered H2O osmotically reabsorbed; not subject to control

50% of filtered urea passively reabsorbed; not subject to control

Almost all filtered K+ reabsorbed; not subject to control

Variable H+ secretion, depending on acid-base status of body

Organic ion secretion; not subject to control
Distal tubule
Reabsorption Secretion

Variable Na+ reabsorption, controlled by aldosterone; Cl– follows passively

Variable H2O reabsorption, controlled by vasopressin

Variable H+ secretion, depending on acid-base status of body

Variable K+ secretion, controlled by aldosterone

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of schizophrenia, and on treatment for drug-induced Parkinson's presents with complaints of constipation, blurred vision, and dry mouth. Which of the following drugs may be responsible for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with Schizophrenia and drug-induced Parkinson's disease with anti-cholinergic symptoms is taking benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). 

Drug-induced Parkinsonism is a condition that is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting antimuscarinic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons. 

The following drugs are implicated in drug-induced parkinsonism:

Drug class

Examples 
Typical antipsychotics

Phenothiazines, haloperidol
Atypical antipsychotics Risperidone, olanzapine
Dopamine depleters Reserpine, tetrabenazine
Antiemetics Metoclopramide, levosulpiride
Calcium channel blockers Flunarizine, cinnarizine

Other options: 

Option A: Lithium is used to treat bipolar disorders and major depressive disorder. The main adverse effects are lithium toxicity, serotonin syndrome, and pseudotumor cerebri. Lithium use is usually avoided in patients with a known cardiovascular disease due to an increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias. 

Option B: Pramipexole is used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and restless leg syndrome. The main adverse effects are dyskinesias and postural deformities. 

Option D: Selegiline is used in the treatment of major depressive disorder and Parkinson's disease. The main adverse effects are serotonin syndrome, somnolence, and exacerbation of hypertension. Hence, it is not preferred in Parkinson's patients with hypertension.

questions.text: A man is brought to the emergency department after falling from a height with his hand outstretched. X-ray shows a clavicular fracture. Which part of the clavicle is most likely to be fractured?
questions.solution:
The junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd (middle third) of the clavicle is most likely to be fractured. 

The middle third of the clavicle is the narrowest and has the least amount of surrounding soft tissue structures. Therefore, most fractures (~80%) are seen in the middle third. 

Fall on the shoulder (direct impact) and fall on the outstretched hand are the most common causes of clavicle fracture.

The patient will be presented with the flexed elbow as the arm will be held to the chest to prevent movement. It is divided into three based on the location of the fractures:

  1. Group I – middle-third fractures
  2. Group II – lateral-third fractures
  3. Group III – medial-third fractures

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the fifth stage of the demographic cycle?

choices.text: Birth rate falls below death rate

questions.solution:
In stage 5 of the demographic cycle, the birth rate falls below the death rate.

In this stage, the death rate attains a low stable rate while the birth rate keeps declining. Thus, the curve of the birth rate will cross the curve of the death rate in a graph of the demographic cycle and falls further below. 

The demographic gap is negative and the population is declining. So, this stage is known as the declining stage.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is undergoing pubertal changes. Her tanner stage is stage 4 for breast development and pubic hair scale. Which of the following pubertal changes is not due to estrogen?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not due to estrogen. It is due to testosterone (in both the sexes).

Puberty in females :

  • Involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche).
  • Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts and reproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips.
  • Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification and cervical mucus production, induce closure of the epiphyses, have a positive effect in maintaining bone formation, and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

In young girls before puberty the vaginal epithelium is thin and comprised of only basal and parabasal layers. During the reproductive years, the vaginal epithelium thickens and develops a distinct cornified layer due to the influence of estrogen. Cervical mucous production and menstruation are also changes occuring under the influence of estrogen and also progesterone.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the conversion of T4 to T3, in the peripheral tissue?
questions.solution:
Peripheral T3 conversion from T4 is catalyzed by the enzyme iodothryronine deiodinase I. T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone. It is expressed predominantly in the peripheral tissues. 

Iodothyronine deiodinase II: Iodothyronine deiodinase type II (DIO2) is an enzyme responsible for the activation of T4 to T3 in certain specific tissues, such as the hypothalamus and pituitary gland.

questions.text: Cervical dilation and delivery on uterine contraction  is similar to which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Milk ejection by oxytocin follows a stimulation mechanism similar to uterine contraction in delivery (cervical dilatation). 

The physiological actions of oxytocin are: 

  • Contraction of the pregnant uterus: Cervical dilatation transmits signals to the hypothalamus and stimulates the secretion of oxytocin, which acts on the smooth muscles of the uterus and contracts it. 
  • Milk ejection from breasts: Suckling reflex transmits signals to the hypothalamus which causes release of oxytocin which acts on the myoepithelial cells of the breast. This results in ejection of milk. 

The action of oxytocin are examples of positive feedback mechanism.

questions.text: A patient underwent a left submandibular gland excision during which the hypoglossal nerve was injured. Which of the following deficits would be seen in this case?

choices.text: Deviated tongue to the contralateral side
Deviated tongue to the same side
Loss of taste in posterior 1/3rd of the tongue

questions.solution:
A hypoglossal nerve injury would damage all muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus resulting in deviation of the tongue to the same side. Since, the left hypoglossal nerve is injured in the above scenario, the tongue will deviate to the left side. 

Hypoglossal nerve injury:

  • Ipsilateral tongue atrophy
  • Paralysis of all muscles except palatoglossus resulting in ipsilateral deviation of the tongue on protrusion
  • Paralysis of geniohyoid and thyrohyoid resulting in deviation of larynx to the contralateral side.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the given image.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dendritic ulcer caused by herpes simplex virus. 

Herpes simplex causes epithelial keratitis and in severe forms, dendritic ulcers develop. Most of the patients present with redness, photophobia, watering, and blurred vision. On examination, visual acuity and corneal sensation are reduced. Follicular conjunctivitis and blepharitis may develop but are usually mild. Clinical reactivation occurs due to multiple stress factors and causes recurrent infections.

The fluorescein-stained image under slit-lamp examination shows dendritic ulcers, a pathognomic feature of epithelial keratitis. They are mostly treated with acyclovir 3% ointment or ganciclovir 0.15% gel.

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

Primary herpes:

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetable matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: High-ceiling diuretics are used in the treatment of all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
High-ceiling diuretics or loop diuretics are used to treat pulmonary edema and are not used in pulmonary hypertension.

They act by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride.

  • Their diuretic property helps in removing the excess fluid in hepatic, renal, and cardiac diseases. Their vasodilatory and diuretic action cause natriuresis reduces left ventricular filling pressures and thereby rapidly relieve pulmonary edema.
    s helpful for the quick relief of symptoms in LVF and acute pulmonary edema. They are also used for the treatment of chronic CHF.
  • Loop diuretics can be used as an adjunct to mannitol in cerebral edema. The osmotic effect of mannitol can be prolonged by the use of a loop diuretic. They preferentially excrete water over solute and maintain blood-brain osmotic gradient established by mannitol.

Pulmonary artery hypertension is a condition where there is increased pulmonary vascular resistance. Since nitric oxide is an important regulator of pulmonary vascular resistance, PDE5 inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, or tadalafil are primarily used in the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: Metastatic calcification occurs in all except _________
questions.solution:
Dystrophic calcification is seen in atheromatous plaque. 

  • Metastatic calcification can occur in normal tissues whenever there is hypercalcemia.
  • The major causes of hypercalcemia are 
    • Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone, due to malignant tumors
    • Paget disease, immobilization, or tumors (increased bone catabolism associated with multiple myeloma, leukemia, or skeletal metastases)
    • Vitamin D intoxication and sarcoidosis
    • Renal failure
  • Metastatic calcification can occur throughout the body, but mainly affects the interstitial tissues of the vasculature, kidneys, lungs, and gastric mucosa.

Related Pearl: Types of calcifications

  Dystrophic calcification Metastatic calcification
Location Dead and dying tissues Normal interstitial tissues of the vasculature, kidneys, lungs, and gastric mucosa.
Calcium metabolism Normal deranged causing hypercalcemia
Examples

Calcific valvular stenosis

Advanced Atheromatous plaque

Monckeberg medial sclerosis

Parathyroid tumors

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Paget disease

vitamin D intoxication

Sarcoidosis

Renal failure

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA replication?

choices.text: Replication can occur only from a single stranded DNA template
Replication can occur only from a double stranded DNA template
Deoxynucleotide polymerization is catalyzed by helicases
Only DNA polymerase  functions at the replication fork

questions.solution:
In all cells, replication can occur only from a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) template.

 Steps of DNA replication:

  • Identification of the origins of replication
  • ATP hydrolysis-driven unwinding of dsDNA to provide an ssDNA template
  • Formation of the replication fork; synthesis of RNA primer
  • Initiation of DNA synthesis and elongation
  • Formation of replication bubbles with ligation of the newly synthesized DNA segments
  • Reconstitution of chromatin structure

Helicase, primase and polymerases act at the replication fork.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male patient suffers trauma to his eye with vegetative matter. He now presents with a corneal ulcer, alongside hypopyon and satellite lesions. He reports mild pain with photophobia and redness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario most likely describes fungal keratitis with ulceration.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. Signs are more pronounced than symptoms. The corneal ulcer appears dry.

Causative organisms:

  • Aspergillus
  • Fusarium
  • Candida albicans

Signs of a fungal ulcer:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer.
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, and immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

Treatment:

  • Topical drugs: These include topical natamycin, voriconazole or amphotericin B drops which are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium. Nystatin is effective against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Severe ulcers with hypopyon, perforation or suspected endophthalmitis might warrant the use of oral antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with untoward side effect of renal tubular damage?
questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity is one of the dose-limiting toxicity of cisplatin therapy. Cisplatin achieves a high concentration in nephrons. Both direct toxicity and inflammation are responsible for nephrotoxicity. A high concentration of chloride stabilizes cisplatin and reduces nephrotoxicity. Therefore, chloride diuresis is used to reduce nephrotoxicity.

Option B: streptozotocin use can result in diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of beta cells of the pancreas.

Option C: methysergide use is associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Option D: cyclophosphamide causes hemorrhagic cystitis as one of its characteristic side effect.

questions.text: The given type of population pyramid indicates all except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows an age pyramid/population pyramid with a broad base and tapering top. The age pyramid is plotted as a younger age at the bottom and older age at the top. Hence this age pyramid represents a higher young population. This pyramid is typical of developing countries, and not developed countries.

This type of pyramid also indicates an increasing population because of high young population reflecting high fertility.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: A boy was diagnosed with a medical condition, which is believed to have been passed down from his grandmother to his father, and now to him. What is the pattern of inheritance in this particular case?
questions.solution:
The said disease shows an autosomal dominant pattern.

In the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, both males and females are equally affected, and the affected individual has a 50% chance of passing it on to the offspring.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

Related Pearl: Autosomal Dominant Disorders

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the urban primary health center staff except _____.
questions.solution:
An urban primary health center will be staffed with two doctors (one regular and one on a part-time basis): 3 staff nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 lab technician, 1 lady health visitor, and 4–5 ANMs (depending upon the population covered.

  • Other clerical and support staff and one program manager for supporting community mobilization, behavior change communication, capacity building efforts and strengthening referrals.
  • One U-PHC will cover 50,000 to 60,000 population.
  • Basic functions will be OPD, basic lab diagnosis, drug/contraceptive dispensing, and health education along with referral services.

International Nurses Day is an international day observed around the world on 12 May of each year, to mark the contributions that nurses make to society.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The type of joint shown in the given image is syndesmosis. 

The radius and ulna are united with each other by three joints:

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

  • The oblique cord - extends from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity to the radius, distal to the radial tuberosity.
  • Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

Based on the structure, joints are classified into three types:

  • Fibrous joints
    • Sutures
    • Syndesmosis
    • Gomphosis
  • Cartilaginous joints
    • Primary cartilaginous joints or synchondrosis
    • Secondary cartilaginous joints or symphysis
  • Synovial joints
    • Ball-and-socket or spheroidal joints
    • Sellar or saddle joints
    • Condylar or bicondylar joints
    • Ellipsoid joints
    • Hinge joints
    • Pivot or trochoid joints
    • Plane joints

The illustration below depicts types of fibrous joints.

The illustration below depicts the types of synovial joints.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is a cauliflower-like growth in the left eye alongside leukocoria and an absent red reflex. A diagnosis was made and enucleation was done. The microscopic appearance of the specimen shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histology, clinical history and gross specimen point towards a diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is due to mutation in the Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma was the first cancer known to be directly associated with a genetic abnormality.

Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Present within the first two years of life
  • Leukocoria 
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis.
  • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases.
  • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumour is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumour projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumour forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain is the investigation of choice.

 The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

questions.text: A boy, upon disturbing a bee hive, received several stings. After a few minutes, he developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. This is an example of ______.
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following a bee sting is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or type 1 hypersensitivity. Injurious immune reactions are called hypersensitivity reactions.

Immediate (type I) hypersensitivity:

  • These are also called allergic reactions or allergies.
  • They are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals
  • IgE coats mast cells by binding to Fcεg receptors; reexposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI, activation of mast cells, and release of mediators.
  • The principal mediators are histamine, proteases, and other granule contents; prostaglandins and leukotrienes; as well as cytokines.
  • The mediators are responsible for the immediate vascular and smooth muscle reactions and the late-phase reaction (inflammation).
  • The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.
  • It occurs in two phases: immediate phase and late phase.

Sequence of events in immediate hypersensitivity:

Related Pearl: Disorders Caused by Immediate Hypersensitivity

Clinical Syndrome

Clinical and Pathologic Manifestations

Anaphylaxis (may be caused by drugs, bee sting, food)

Fall in blood pressure (shock) caused by vascular dilation; airway obstruction due to laryngeal edema

Bronchial asthma

Airway obstruction caused by bronchial smooth muscle hyperactivity; inflammation and tissue injury caused by late-phase reaction

Allergic rhinitis, sinusitis (hay fever)

Increased mucus secretion; inflammation of upper airways, sinuses

Food allergies

Increased peristalsis due to contraction of intestinal muscles

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea.  On further evaluation, the patient was found to have cutaneous flushing, extensive wheeze, and tricuspid insufficiency. Contrast enhanced-MRI revealed the presence of endocardial fibrosis. Which of the following substances will be excreted excessively in this patient?
questions.solution:
5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) will be excreted excessively in the above given clinical scenario, as this is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is due to excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism. It is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA. It is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhoea. 

Note:

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific to carcinoid tumours. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumours associated with carcinoid syndrome.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical ‘swallow tails’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as a/an ___________________
questions.solution:
The characteristics described are consistent with that of a lacerated wound

The characteristics of a lacerated wound:

The margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails.

The edges of the laceration may indicate a direction, in which the blow or force was applied. Depth of the wound shows bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels, and nerves and can be soiled by mud, sand, glass, brick particles, vegetation, machine oils, hair, or fibers. These materials embedded in the wound are of great medicolegal value.

Lacerated wounds do not bleed much as the vessels are crushed and torn, thus facilitating hemostasis. The exception to this is injuries to the scalp, where temporal arteries may bleed freely as they are firmly bound and unable to contract. Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed and buried into the depth of the wound. Because of the crushing and tearing nature of the production of lacerations, there can be associated abrasion or bruising.

 Swallow tail in a Lacerated wound

 

Fishtails - These may be seen in stab wounds where the skin splits at the corner. 

Chop wounds: called because of the action in which they are produced. Depending on the type of instrument, they may resemble an incised or a lacerated wound. The shape of the wound may give clues to the type of weapon. For example, in the given image, the wound resembles an injury produced by a sharp axe. Such wounds may be inflicted with homicidal intent on the skull/scalp. Chop wounds are usually deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon like an axe, sword, hatchet etc

questions.text: A young boy suffers trauma to his right eye and develops monocular diplopia. What is the most likely cause for his symptom?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for the boy's symptom is iridodialysis. 

Iridodialysis refers to the detachment of the iris root from the ciliary body and is associated with a D-shaped pupil. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery at the site of detachment.

Causes of Uniocular Diplopia:

  1. Refractive errors
  2. Dry eye syndrome
  3. Corneal abnormalities
  4. Cataracts
  5. Retinal disorders

Causes of Binocular Diplopia:

  1. Strabismus
  2. Cranial nerve palsy
  3. Graves' disease
  4. Trauma or injury
  5. Multiple sclerosis
  6. Myasthenia gravis
 Other options:
  • Festooned pupil - It is seen in posterior synechiae with the adhesion of the pupillary margin to the lens capsule.
  • Iris bombe refers to the forward bowing of the iris seen in closed-angle glaucoma with irido-lenticular contact and in seclusio pupillae with 360-degree posterior synechiae. Drainage of aqueous is blocked due to the irido-lenticular apposition and pressure of the accumulated aqueous causes the iris to bow forward.
  • Iridodonesis refers to a tremulous iris caused by a lack of support. It is seen in pseudophakia after cataract surgery and in lens dislocation.

questions.text: A tourist with a travel history to India presents with complaints of abdominal pain and multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. He reports having food at a local restaurant the previous night. Which of the following antidiarrheal agents is used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a tourist with abdominal pain, and multiple episodes of diarrhea following food intake at an unhygienic place is suggestive of the traveller’s diarrhea, most commonly caused by Enterotoxigenic E.Coli. The antidiarrheal agent used in the given scenario is loperamide. 

Loperamide is generally indicated in non-infective diarrhea, but it is also given as an anti-diarrheal agent in traveller's diarrhea in addition to antibiotics.

It is an opioid receptor agonist and slows intestinal motility by direct effects on the circular and longitudinal muscles. It reduces fecal volume and increases viscosity. It is used in traveller's diarrhea for symptomatic treatment in conjunction with antibiotics. It is avoided in patients with dysentery. 

Other options: 

Option A: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog effective in treating severe secretory diarrhea that occurs due to hormone-secreting tumors in the GIT and pancreas. Its use is limited in traveller's diarrhea. 

Option C: Rifaximin is an antibiotic used in the treatment of traveller's diarrhea. It is an alternative to Azithromycin due to poor absorption. 

Option D: Bismuth subsalicylate is an over-the-counter (OTC) preparation used as an antidiarrheal agent. It is used in the treatment of traveller's diarrhea but is not preferred over loperamide due to a requirement for large doses, and salicylate toxicity, especially in high-risk groups (pregnancy, children, and individuals who take aspirin).

questions.text: A farmer presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the treatment of the condition?

choices.text: Atropine is used as an antidote for OP poisoning
Pralidoxime has a role in reversing the enzyme in carbamate poisoning
Succinylcholine use is avoided in rapid sequence intubation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of organophosphate poisoning. 

Oximes like pralidoxime are used to restore neuromuscular transmission in organophosphate anti­ChE poisoning. It attaches to the anionic site of the cholinesterase enzyme, which remains unoccupied in the presence of organophosphates. It binds and forms oxime-phosphonate which diffuses away, leaving the reactivated cholinesterase.

Pralidoxime is not an effective anti­dote to carbamates like carbaryl. This is because the anionic site of the cholinesterase enzyme is not free for attachment to pralidoxime. Hence, it does not reactivate the carbamylated enzyme. Carbamates spontaneously disassociate from AChE and recover in 24-48 hours.

Pralidoxime may potentiate the toxicity of carbaryl. Therefore, pralidoxime should be avoided in known single-agent carbaryl poisonings. However, pralidoxime is considered for use in mixed poisonings with an organophosphorus compound and a carbamate. 

Atropine is useful in organophosphate poisoning because it is a competitive antagonist of acetylcholine. An acetylcholinesterase enzyme has an active and anionic site. The organophosphates bind to the active site of AChEs (acetylcholine esterases) and deactivate it. This results in excessive Ach causing muscarinic activity. It has relatively insignificant action on nicotinic receptors. 

Organophosphates and carbamates are powerful acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. They bind irreversibly to acetylcholinesterases. 

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headache, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Patients who present with organophosphate and carbamate poisoning require early endotracheal intubation to avoid respiratory depression, which is a common complication. Succinylcholine is avoided due to its metabolism by acetylcholinesterase which leads to prolonged neuromuscular blockade. 

Related Pearl: Drugs used in Organophosphorus Poisoning

Drug

Symptoms for which it is used

Atropine

Muscarinic symptoms and CNS effects

Pralidoxime

Nicotinic symptoms

Diacetyl monoxime-specific cholinesterase reactivator

Nicotinic >muscarinic and CNS effects

Convulsions

Pulmonary oedema, bronchospasm

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency. On examination, his PR is 50 bpm,  BP is 80/60 mmHg, RR is 7 breaths/min and his temperature is 95 F. He has pin point pupils and is disoriented.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Opioid intoxication is the most probable diagnosis in the above given clinical scenario. Opioids include morphine, heroin, codeine, etc. 

Symptoms of opioid overdose:

  • Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils(miosis)
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Shallow breathing
  • Hypothermia

Characteristics of opioid toxicity:

  • Opioid intoxication toxidrome - respiratory and mental status depression, analgesia, miosis, orthostatic hypotension, nausea and vomiting, histamine release resulting in localized urticaria and bronchospasm, ileus secondary to decreased GI motility, and urinary retention secondary to increased vesical sphincter tone.
  • Miosis is not universally present from intoxication with every opioid; normal or even enlarged pupils have been documented secondary to diphenoxylate, meperidine, morphine, pentazocine, and propoxyphene toxicity.
  • Opioid-induced acute lung injury, previously known as non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, is an uncommon complication associated with heroin overdose.
Opioid receptor Actions
mu

Analgesia

Sedation

Miosis

Respiratory depression

Cough suppression

Euphoria

Decreased GI motility
kappa

Analgesia

Sedation

Miosis

Decreased GI motility

Dysphoria

Hallucinations
delta

Analgesia

Antidepressant effect

Airway protection and ventilatory maintenance are the most important treatment steps for opioid intoxications, because respiratory depression is the major morbidity and the cause of essentially all the mortality.

  • After adequate ventilation is ensured, administer naloxone.
  • Single-dose activated charcoal can be administered in case opioid ingestion occured within one hour.

Opioid withdrawal symptoms (mnemonic- O MY WITHDRAWALS):

  • Mydriasis
  • Yawning
  • Weakness
  • Insomnia, irritability
  • Tremors, tachycardia
  • Hyperthermia, hypertension
  • Diarrhea
  • Rhinorrhoea
  • Apnoeic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Anxiety
  • Lacrimation
  • Sweating

questions.text: Which of the following is involved as a secondary messenger in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion?
questions.solution:
cAMP is the secondary messenger involved in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion.

cGMP is not involved in gastric acid secretion. Ach acts on the synapses, and CCK-B receptors interact with gastrin to contribute to gastric acid secretion. They also act via secondary messengers such as IP3 and increased intracellular Ca2+.

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: The cells responsible for graft rejection are:
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, T-cells are responsible for graft rejection.

Graft rejection is both humoral and cell-mediated in nature. It is a process in which T-cells and antibodies produced against graft antigens react against tissue grafts and destroy it.

The major antigenic differences that result in the rejection of transplants are differences in HLA alleles. The recipient T-cells are involved in the recognition of the donor MHC molecules and mount an immune response. Depending on the antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that are involved in T-cell activation, there are 2 pathways:

  • Direct pathway of allorecognition - MHC antigens are presented by the APCs in the graft
  • Indirect pathway of allorecognition - MHC antigens are presented by the recipient’s own APCs (e.g., macrophages)

The early activation of NK cells kill allogeneic target cells directly or via antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and release various chemokines and immunomodulatory cytokines.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the abdominal plane labeled 2?
questions.solution:
The structure marked 2 in the given image is the subcostal plane. It is at the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The subcostal plane is an anatomical reference plane used in clinical and surgical practice. It is defined as a horizontal plane passing through the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage bilaterally. The 10th costal cartilage corresponds approximately to the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The costal cartilages are extensions of the ribs that articulate with the sternum anteriorly. The 10th costal cartilage is the cartilage of the 10th rib.

In the given image, structure 2 represents the subcostal plane, which corresponds to the level of the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage. Since the 10th costal cartilage is at the level of the upper border of L3, it indicates that the subcostal plane is also at the level of the upper border of L3.

Other options: As mentioned earlier, the subcostal plane is positioned at the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3), not L1 or L2 or L4.

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions

  • Horizontal planes 
    • L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). Corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). Corresponds to the origin of Inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (Paramedian or lateral planes)
    • Mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Left hypochondriac, Epigastric, Right hypochondriac
  • Left lumbar, Umbilical (Central), Right lumbar
  • Left iliac, Hypogastric (Suprapubic), Right iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • The supracristal plane passing through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. Posteriorly, it corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. When supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle is the angle between the 12th rib and the outer border of Erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle (of Petit) is marked below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar herniation can occur here.

questions.text: 4-8 speakers talk about a specific topic in front of a large audience. There is no particular agenda, set speech, or order of speaking. In the end, there is interaction with the audience.  What is this mode of communication best known as?
questions.solution:
The given premise best denotes a panel discussion. 

In a panel discussion,

  • 4 to 8 experts are allowed to have a discussion on a topic in front of an audience.
  • No speeches or order is set beforehand.
  • A moderator is present to regulate the discussion.
  • The audience is invited to speak after the discussion and ask questions.
Methods of Health Communication    
Individual approach Group approach Mass approach
  1. Personal contact
  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1. Lectures
  2. Demonstrations
  3. Discussion methods
    • Group discussions
    • Panel discussion
    • Symposium
    • Workshop
    • Conferences
    • Seminars
    • Role play
  1. TV
  2. Radio
  3. Newspaper
  4. Printed material
  5. Direct mailing
  6. Posters
  7. Health museums
  8. Health exhibitions
  9. Folk method
  10. Internet

Other options:

A symposium is a series of speeches on a selected subject by experts. Each expert presents an aspect of the subject briefly, after which the audience is allowed to ask questions. There is no discussion among symposium members. The chairman makes a comprehensive summary at the end of the session.

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within a group, with the use of external consultants or experts. It can be divided into small groups each with a chairman and recorder. Each individual solves a part of the problem and leaves the workshop with a plan of action.

Seminars are similar to conferences and it incorporates a variety of methods like speeches, discussions for health education, and may last for half a day to a week.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days. Examination reveals a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate. His chest X-ray showed subglottic narrowing appearing like a steeple. Which among the following is not indicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever, and increased respiratory rate and an X-ray showing subglottic narrowing appearing like a steeple is suggestive of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis). Parenteral cefotaxime is not indicated in its treatment.

The median age for laryngotracheobronchitis is 3 months to 5 years. It is caused due to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions. Patients present with low-grade fever,  barking cough, hoarseness of voice, and inspiratory stridor. 

The image below shows a steeple sign, seen in croup.

Treatment of croup involves:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization - It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption from the interstitial space and reduction of edema. The indications for the administration of nebulized epinephrine are:
    • moderate to severe stridor at rest
    • the possible need for intubation
    • respiratory distress
    • hypoxia
  • Oral dexamethasone - Indicated in all the grades of croup. Corticosteroids reduce laryngeal edema through their anti-inflammatory action. IM dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equal clinical effect. Corticosteroids should not be administered to children with varicella or tuberculosis as they may worsen the disease.
  • A helium-oxygen mixture (heliox) may be considered for severe croup when intubation is being considered. Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

Most children that have croup can be managed safely at home. Indications for hospitalization:

  • Progressive stridor
  • Severe stridor at rest
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypoxia
  • Cyanosis
  • Depressed mental status
  • Poor oral intake
  • Need for reliable observation

NOTE:

As the duration of action of racemic epinephrine is only less than 2 hours, it is mandatory to place the patient on observation for 2-3 hours to watch for the reappearance of symptoms. The patient can be discharged home if he has:

  • No stridor at rest
  • Normal air entry
  • Normal O2 saturation
  • Normal level of consciousness
  • Received steroids

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes the sensation as a curtain being drawn over his affected eye. In addition, 7 days ago the patient noticed what he described as flashing lights and floaters. He gives a history of having cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. A B-scan image of his left eye is shown below. What could be his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. It is due to the accumulation of fluid between neurosensory retina(NSR) and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to a retinal tear.

Definition of retinal detachment: The separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE.

Types of Retinal detachment:

A. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment- fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina.

  • Causes:
    • High myopes
    • Retinoschisis-splitting of neurosensory retina plus vitreous degeneration
      • Typical retinoschisis-split at the level of the outer plexiform layer
      • Atypical retinoschisis-split at the level of the nerve fiber layer
    • Trauma
    • Pseudophakia
    • Aphakia
  • The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear.
  • The most dangerous location of retinal break is the supero-temporal retina. 
  • Clinical features
    • Photopsia-flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break
    • Floaters
    • Visual field defect- a black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Hypotony- as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE.
    • Shafers sign-pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations.
  • Treatment
    • Prophylactic laser barrage
    • Scleral buckling
    • Pneumatic retinopexy
    • Pars plana vitrectomy 

B. Tractional retinal detachment: Fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. 

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Central retinal venous occlusion
    • Eales disease
    • Retinopathy of Prematurity(ROP)
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen
  • Treatment
    • Pars plana vitrectomy with endo photocoagulation. 

C. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative fluid from the choroid, collects in the subretinal space leading to retinal detachment.

  • Causes
    • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
    • Choroidal tumours like melanoma
    • Toxaemia of pregnancy
    • Malignant hypertension
    • Coats disease
  • Clinical features
    • Floaters due to vitritis but no photopsia
    • Visual field defect
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is seen.
    • Shifting fluid is seen.
  • Treatment
    • Systemic steroids
    • Treatment of the cause

 The image below shows a fundus which reveals retinal detachment inferiorly from 3-9 o'clock with a tear at 3:30

questions.text: Which of the following conditions gives the haematological picture as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given haematological picture showing basophilic stippling with Cabot's ring is suggestive of chronic lead poisoning also called as plumbism or saturnism.

Clinical features of lead poisoning include

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling.
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums).
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain).
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy.
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma).
  • F - Facial pallor -earliest sign.

Other Options:

Option A : Minamata disease is chronic mercury poisoning can show anemia secondary to GI hemorrhage.

Option C : Chronic iron toxicity, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).

Option D : Arsenic poisoning can induce microcytic hypochromic anemia or hemolytic anemia.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

 Features Lead
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action

binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits

  • ALA dehydratase
  • ferrochelatase

inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase

competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract

Bone marrow

Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS

Renal
Characteristic clinical findings

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)
